head_text.subj: EXT. MOORLAND YORKSHIRE LATE WINTER AFTERNOON

text: A HIGH ANGLED SHOT of a young WOMAN dressed in the hiking style of the early thirties running across wild Moorland. We are too far away clearly to be able to identify her fa MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: ANOTHER PART OF THE YORKSHIRE MOORLAND LATE AFTERNOO

text: The WOMAN HIKER is seen from the back, running through he and splashing through a stream MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: ANOTHER PART OF THE YORKSHIRE MOORLAND LATE AFTERNOO

text: The WOMAN HIKER seen from the back climbs out of the stre and gains a rough track leading over a small stone bridge She runs over it and disappears into the melancholy countryside. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT, YORKSHIRE VILLAGE HIGH STREET DUSK

text: The village street is empty. Prominent is a Police Statio The WOMAN HIKER, again seen from the back, runs panting i it.
A POLICE SERGEANT sits at a desk. The HIKER, again seen from the back, rushes up to him.
Murder! ... Murder! ...You must come at once! There's a woman lying dead out at Marley Copse. I think she's been strangled.

A HIGH SHOT of a police car racing through the countrysid It is driven by a POLICE CONSTABLE. Next to him is the POLICE SURGEON. Two figures are dimly perceived sitting i the back seat. One is the WOMAN HIKER. The other is helmeted. We hear their conversation, but never go inside the car, or get a clear view of the features of the WOMAN  6 Continued
Now madam, what time did you say it was when you found the body?
About a quarter past four ... I think she'd only just been killed.
How did you know that? Did you see anybody hanging about?
No. But she was still warm. The car races away from CAMERA, over the Moors.
A torch breaks the darkness and lights up the distorted f of ALICE CORRIGAN. The strangled body lies in deepish bra Beside it kneels a POLICE SURGEON.
Let's see, It's now six o'clock. I'd say she'd been dead no more than two hours. Say four o'clock, as the outside for time of death.
The young woman said she was still warm when she found her at four fifteen sir.
Well, so she would have been. Warm as toast.

head_text.subj: INT. OFFICE OF THE TROJAN INSURANCE COMPANY DAY

text: A SENIOR EXECUTIVE of the Trojan Insurance Company sits a desk reading some papers. There is a knock at the door an looks up eagerly as a young female SECRETARY comes in.
Hercules Parrot, sir. The SECRETARY withdraws as HERCULE POIROT enters. He carr a folder of papers. The EXECUTIVE rises and indicates a c on the other side of the desk.
Good morning Monsieur Poirot. Please take a seat,  Continued
Bon Jour Monsieur. He sits in the proffered seat as the EXECUTIVE regains hi own chair.
Well, I hope you have some good news for me.

Alas no. I regret that I can find nothing in these reports to justify my re-investigating this case for you. It is dll perfectly clear from the police reports. I know Mrs Alice Corrigan insured her life with your company, in her husband's favour, and that, he was the only person with a motive for killing her, but when it comes down to the copper tacks, he could not possibly have done so. Clearly on the evidence, the lady was murdered between four o'clock and four fifteen, when the body was found at Marley Copse. From two o'clock to four twenty, Mr Edward Corrigan was seen by at least half a dozen people to be on a train coming up from London. And the railway station was a good fifteen minutes walk from Marley Copse. Non, it is, parbleu, one of those rare cases where the Insurance Company must, aS you say, laugh and lump it. .
Well if that's your view Monsieur Poirot, then I suppose we'll have to er - do just that. I must say I'm not surprised. The evidence is most conclusive. Still we had hoped ...

For a miracle? Alas it is not possible. 4s is most often the case in les affaires criminelles, the facts are exactly as they appear to be. I wish you good day, Monsieur. POIROT rises, bows and departs, leaving the folder of pap on the table. A SLOW MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  10 11 12 13 4

An establishing SHOT of Smugglers' Island basking in the afternoons's sun. A rowing boat is approaching the Island with four figures in it. WE TRACK IN towards the nautical windows of the bar of the Jolly Roger Hotel.

head_text.subj: INT. THE BAR OF THE JOLLY ROGER HOTEL LATE AFTERNOON

text: DAPHNE CASTLE, a flamboyant fortyish ex-courtesan, now proprietress of the Jolly Roger Hotel stands in the bar straightening her hair, and generally putting the finishi touches to her appearance. It is about five o'clock on a summer's evening. She looks out of the bottle glass windo down at the strip of water which separates the Island fro the Mainland.
A SHOT of the rowing boat approaches the Island seen through the bottle glass windows from DAPHNE CASTLE's poi of view.

head_text.subj: INT. THE BAR OF THE JOLLY ROGER HOTEL LATE AFTERNOON

text: DAPHNE CASTLE reacts with satisfaction.

BILL the Boatman is rowing three guests across from the M land. He is a typical Salt. In the boat are MR and MRS ODELL GARDENER, an American couple from New York. She is large, with blue rinsed hair and diamante spectacles worn a chain. He is thin, tall, slightly stooped and legalisti with a scrawny neck topped by a turtle shaped head. The last occupant of the boat is MISS AGNES BREWSTER, an athletic, middle~aged spinster, who cloaks her vulnerabil under a gruff manner.
(looking towards the Island) Ah! Smugglers’ Island! My, doesn't it look romantic. I can just see Warner Baxter and Elissa Landi in a movie, set here, can't you Odell?
Yes dear.  13 Continued

It would have to be something; like the kidnapping of a Sheik's daughter by a brigand of the sea ... Oriental Pride yields to Piratical kisses in a duel of male might and female charm. An exotic drama of love's sublime cruelty. She sighs rapturously.

I believe they have already used those particular phrases to describe the motion picture "In Her Arms" dear, though I pelieve on that occasion they were Parisian kisses to which Oriental Pride yielded.

(firmly) Well never mind about that Odell. In the Jolly Roger Hotel it would darn well yield to a Pirate's busses. (to Miss Brewster) We're Myra and Odell Gardener by the way. From New York City. MR and MRS GARDENER extend their hands. MISS BREWSTER sha
How do you do, I'm Agnes Brewster. I hope you are enjoying your holiday.
It's been just great. We've been doing England. MISS BREWSTER And have you done it?

Sure. Canterbury Cathedral. The Crown Jewels, Lords Croquet Ground, though those gentlemen weren't playing the day we were there - you know the whole box of tricks. But enough is enough. Last week I said to Mr Kelso at Cooks, sight seeing is all very well, but all I want now is to get to some quiet spot in the Mediterranean and just relax. Mind you, I said not just anywhere. Oh no. It had to be sanitary. A cousin of Odell's went to a place in Wales last year where they only had an earth closet. Isn't it so Odell?  13 14 «EXT. Continued
Two earth closets I think it was, dear. One for the guests and one for the servants. Mind you, I believe it was very picturesque.

(sharply) Picturesque or not, you'd think at least they'd have been able to provide the paying customers with a water closet. (to Miss Brewster) You British sometimes take this Olde Worlde charm to quite ludicrous lengths.

It's just that we don't believe in pampering ourselves that's all. It's my belief that all that central heating you have in America saps the energy of the nation, aside from being extremely bad for the complexion, It encourages -acne in the young, and craters in the not so young. (to Bill the Boatman) Come along Boatman, dig those oars in! Pull with a will! BILL gives her a sour look and rows even more lethargical than he has been doing. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: THE TERRACE OF THE JOLLY ROGER HOTEL LATE AFTERNOON

text: DAPHNE CASTLE stands on the terrace of the Jolly Roger Ho welcoming MR and MRS GARDENER and MISS BREWSTER. In the background two servants BERT and CHARLIE struggle up the steps from the tiny harbour to the hotel carrying baggage
I am Dapline Castle, let me welcome you to Smugglers' Island. I do hope you'll be most comfortable here.
I think Mr and Mrs Gardener are a little concerned about earth closets.
Earth closets! What can you possibly mean Miss Brewster?  14 15 Continued
Perhaps I should explain that my wife is somewhat suspicious of lavatorial systems which are not indigenous to the United States of America, Mrs Castile.

(to Mrs Gardener) I'm sure you will find all the loos here perfectly adequate Mrs Gardener. We even bave bidets in all the bath- rooms, If you will please follow me. DAPHNE CASTLE moves off towards the hotel, followed by MISS BREWSTER.
I tend to believe that bidets are basically un-American, Odell. Still I suppose we'll have to put up with them. The GARDENERS follow the others towards the Hotel.

BILL rows his boat towards Smugglers’ Island. It contains MR BLATT, a jolly, coarse, life-and-soul-of-the-party, se made man, and PATRICK REDFERN and his wife CHRISTINE REDF He is a good looking young Irishman, fair-haired, and athletic. She is fair skinned, pleasant looking in a somewhat washed-out way. They are sitting in a reserved silence. MR BLATT inevitably decides to start the ball rolling.

Well, well, well! Might as well break the ice. Blatt's the name. Horace Blatt. Beef or mutton. L for leather. Aphorism. Tea for two, twice. Got it? He laughs considerably at his own oft repeated witticism.
I'm Patrick Redfern, and this is my wife Christine. They smile at each other.  15 16 17 Continued
A Mick?
Well I come from Dublin actually, but I haven’t been back for years.
I say, I say, I say. How do you make an Irishman burn his ear?
Ring him up when he's ironing. It wasn't very funny when I first heard it five years ago. MR BLATT, crushed, looks away towards the Island.

head_text.subj: INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR AND VIEW OF BEDROOMS EVENING

text: The two servants BERT and CHARLIE are putting the luggage the allocated bedrooms. WE TRACK DOWN a long corridor following DAPHNE CASTLE to see through open doors that MR AND MRS GARDENER, MISS BREWSTER and MR HORACE BLATT have already established themselves in their rooms. Unpacking has started, and we hear the sound of baths being run. She approaches the REDFERNS' room.

head_text.subj: INT. MR AND MRS REDFERNS' BEDROOM EVENING

text: MR and MRS REDFERN are starting to unpack. CHARLIE is just retiring through the open door, as DAPHNE CASTLE app in it.
Mr and Mrs Redfern?
Yes.
I'm Daphne Castle - the Pirate Chief. Welcome to Smugglers' Island.
Thank you. It all looks marvellous. I'm sure we'll have a nice time here.  17 Continued
Well a bit naughty I hope too.
Naughty?
Well what are hols for if one can't do a bit of flirting, and get a bit pissyboos?
Quite right. - CHRISTINE shoots her husband a venomous look.

Yes, when fate cast me up here on this old rock, I said to myself people are going to have fun in a crazy old English atmosphere even though it's in the Med. So you'll find the servants are all English and properly trained, and there's lots of games to play and of course there's great grub.
Ah now we're talking. Most English hotels fall down in that department. Cold mutton and cabinet pudding are not my idea of holiday nourishment.

I don't think you'll find that either dish features on darling Andrea's menus. Let's face it, he is almost the greatest saucier in the Aegean. I say almost, because he does have a slightly hysterical hand with the créme fraiche, But it is a fault on the right side. See you for cocktails around seven. She breezes out.
Funny lady. He takes a robe and swimming trunks from his suitcase and goes into the bathroom.  17 18 19 10 Continued
What do you think she meant by fate casting her up on this old rock?
Don't you know the story? She used to be the mistress of King Zog of Albania, and when he married he gave her this island.
Provided she kept away, I suppose. Generous fellow.

Wise fellow. Wives don't much like girl friends hanging around the place - or didn't you know that either? PATRICK REDFERN walks into the room, wearing only a swimm costume. and carrying his robe. We note his fine physique There is a moment of tension between them.
Yes, I had noticed. Toodle doo. He leaves the room jauntily. CHRISTINE looks after him speculatively then moves to the window to look out. Her face hardens at what she sees.

We see the harbour from CHRISTINE REDFERN's point of view The rowing boat is just being made fast by BILL. In it ar CAPTAIN KENNETH MARSHALL, a well groomed slightly stern man of about forty five years old, his wife ARLENA MARSHA a tall stunning red head of about thirty years old, and his daughter (her step daughter) LINDA MARSHALL, @ gauche unformed, unhappy girl of fifteen or so.

head_text.subj: EXT, THE JETTY IN THE HARBOUR EVENING

text: The MARSHALLS step ashore. At the same moment PATRICK RED passes them on a path which leads down to the Hotel Beach He stops when he catches sight of ARLENA, his face regist surprised delight. Then his gaze travels uneasily to her husband and back again, to ARLENA.
Why hullo Arlena.  11 19 Continued
Dahling! Fancy meeting you here, of all places. What an astounding coin- eidence.
By St. Patrick himself and all the snakes in Ireland it is that.
Do you know my husband, Kenneth?
Hullo there.
How do you do.

Patrick and I met in London at the Gordons a couple of weeks ago. You remember, I told you about it, Ken. They had that marvellous Josephine Baker singing there. She sings Les Mots D'Amour, directing it in a very obviou way at PATRICK REDFERN. Quite abruptly she stops singing suddenly There is turns on LINDA.
This is my step-daughter Linda, Cloud aside to Linda) Stop standing there all pink and sticky like a half eaten’ marshmallow, and say good evening to Mr Redfern.
(mumbling) Good evening.
Good evening Linda. an awkward moment of tension.

Well I'll be taking myself off to have my dip. See you all later. ARLENA MARSHALL looks after him appreciatively, as he wal off down towards the beach. Her husband and step daughter regard her with somewhat less than the same pleasure. The  19 20 21 12 Continued CAMERA PANS round and tracks in towards CHRISTINE REDFERN window, to see her still standing at it looking down. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
BILL rows his boat raggedly towards the Island. In the stern sits HERCULE POIROT in acute distress.
Ma foie. Cannot you row this boat more calmly?
Gawd bless you sir. It's calmer than a cup of tea today.
I have never found anything calming about a cup of tea. It is simply a device used by the English to underscore tension.
Well you ought to see it somedays ~- waves like roller coasters! POIROT groans and clasps his stomach.

In the glassed in sun lounge DAPHNE CASTLE's cocktail par is in full swing. MR and MRS GARDENER are talking to MR and MRS REDFERN and MISS BREWSTER. CAPTAIN MARSHALL and h daughter are talking to each other. DAPHNE CASTLE and a COUPLE OF MAIDS - GLADYS NORRACOTT, and BETTY TRUMBLE - are moving anxiously through the room serving canapes and drinks. In the general chatter of conversation we pas close by HORACE BLATT telling POIROT a dirty joke.

You see this feller comes running down the hospital corridor, holding his privates, pursued by the nurse carrying a bowl of boiling water. And following them is the doctor yelling "No nurse. What I said was prick his boil". .  21 13 Continued MR BLATT collapses into gales of laughter and moves away. The CAMERA TRACKS into a CLOSE UP of a baffled POIROT as he is joined by DAPHNE CASTLE and BETTY TRUMBLE holdin a tray of drinks.
How about a cocktail Monsieur Poirot?
What would you suggest, Madame? DAPHNE CASTLE points to the various glasses on the tray a she names them.
A White Lady? A Sidecar? A Mainbrace? A Between The Sheets? A King Zog? POIROT examines the last named in its tall frosted glass, dubiously. :
And what might be in that one Madame?
Mostly 151% Bacardi -Arejo Rum. It'll grow hair on your eyeballs.
I do not believe that my eyes need to be that guarded, Madame, but if you have a little Creme de Cassis, or perhaps a Sirop de Fraises, I should be most content.
(doubtfully) Sounds a bit soppy to me but I'll see what I can do.

Merci, Madame. BETTY TRUMBLE leaves with her tray of drinks to circulate through the party. She is replaced at a sign from DAPHNE CASTLE by GLADYS NORRACOTT bearing a tray of Canapés. Prominent are some multicoloured ones, and others formed into the shape of smiling black faces.

Meanwhile how about a Rainbow's End, or a nice Birmingham Smile. They're both tres Muresque - you know, very moreish.  21 14 Continued The dish of canapes is proffered and POIROT takes one. DAPHNE CASTLE's attention is distracted by MR and MRS RED who are in animated conversation with the GARDENERS, and a bright backwards looking smile at POIROT she swoops dow on them.

Ah, Mr Redfern, what did I tell you. Everybody enjoys themselves here. It's not called the Jolly Roger for nothing - even though the name might be said to be more appropriate to an amusing brothel. Behind her POIROT bites into his canape. Creamed Crab spurts out over the lapel of his jacket. The CAMERA MOVES with DAPHNE CASTLE as she joins KENNETH and LINDA MARSHAL In the background POIROT dabs ruefully at his clothing wi a handkerchief, and unashamedly listens.
By Jove, Daphne, you've been successful since we last met - how long ago is it?
It must be a good seventeen years Linda certainly wasn't born. As a matter of fact I don't think you'd even married your first wife then.

No, I don't think I had. Poor Mary she had such an unhappy life. But let's not talk about her. Let's talk about you. You're rich and famous - everyone’s heard about this crazy hotel of yours - it's always in the glossies.
Poor and infamous you mean. They laugh intimately together. Seriously, you shouldn't believe every- thing you hear Kenneth. I'm not that much changed from the daft Daphne you used to know at Shipley.
Were you at Shipley? Daddy's told me so much about it.  21 22 15 Continued
Yes, we were neighbours for years. Do you remember the day we took Toby down to the river to get water rats, and you pushed me in in my best dress?
Absolutely. And you flew into the most frightful rage, and half choked me to death,
Not me, It's impossible. The only attack I've ever made on anyone was when I threw my spaghetti alla yongole at Mussolini for trying to grope me under the table in the Vatican.

What rot! You used to fly into the most fearful rages in those days. We all had to watch our ps and qs a bit. Ah here comes Arlena now ... ARLENA MARSHALL enters the room. She is dramatically attired and gorgeous to look at. Conversation ceases on t instant as all eyes turn towards her. PATRICK REDFERN takes a few steps in her direction, his arms outstretched and we freeze the picture. A series of quick cuts establish the company's reactions. SLOW MIX THROUGH to the next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE TERRACE ABOVE THE BATHING BEACH MORNING

text: HERCULE POIROT arrayed in a white duck suit lies in a dec chair surveying the sunlit scene below. Sunbathing on the beach are MR and MRS REDFERN (the latter in the shade of umbrella), HORACE BLATT, KENNETH MARSHALL and LINDA MARSH and MR and MRS GARDENER. DAPHNE CASTLE is swimming. MISS BREWSTER sits beside POIROT on the terrace.
I understand you are a very distinguished detective Monsieur Poirot.
People have been felicitous enough to have told me that I have some slight skill in that metier, Madame.  16 22 Continued
I do hope we 're not going to have any bodies on Smugglers' Island.

Let me assure you Madame I am here simply to spend the holiday. I do not even think of crime. And yet as to bodies, what are they? He points down to the beach below. Regard them there lying out in rows like corpses in the morgue. They are not men and women. There is nothing personal about them. They are just bodies, like butchers' meat on Slabs. Chunks of flesh grilling in the sun. When I was young one barely saw even the ankle.

(firmly) I must say though that I think the things we wear nowadays are much more sensible. The air must be allowed to circulate freely round the body. A healthy mind in a healthy body, that's my motto and I keep mine healthy rowing. POIROT looks down self-consciously at his expansive paunc MISS BREWSTER notices.
You'd soon have that off if you rowed Monsieur Poirot.

Mademoiselle I detest boats. I have the mal de mer. Even my bath gives me sea sickness. On the beach we see CHRISTINE REDFERN get up from under h umbrella,.and start to walk up the steps towards the hote PATRICK REDFERN goes down the beach to swim. The CAMERA ZOOMS in for a moment to isolate him as he plunges in and starts to swim, using a powerful crawl stroke.  22 Continued

(half Voice Over Patrick Redfern swimming and half direct speech) How unfortunate. I suppose it's a bit like heights. Some people can't stand them. I'm not very good myself, but Mrs Redfern is far worse. Why only this morning on the cliff path above Keelhaul Caves, she turned giddy and simply clung to me, quite unable to move. 17 CHRISTINE REDFERN comes up to the group. Her skin noticea very white, Hullo dear. We were just talking about you.
It's a wonder my ears weren't burning. Everywhere else does, so easily.
You don't like the sunbathing, Madame?

I only wish I could but I don't go brown. I just become like a cassata ~ pink skin, white blisters, and green in the face. Polite laughter while she puts on her robe. Isn't it blissful here. So tranquil. So far away from all trouble and violence.

It is true the sky is blue, and the sun shines, but you forget Madame, everywhere there is evil under the sun. ARLENA MARSHALL walks down from the hotel to the beach, passing the group. She is very suntanned, and wears a bac less white bathing suit. On her head she wears a fantasti Chinese hat of jade green cardboard. She moves with super assurance and the whole effect is rather like a stage ent
Ah, Madame Marshall! What was her stage name?  22 23 24 18 Continued
(sharply) Arlena Stuart.
Oh yes. I saw her in Come and Go a couple of years ago at the Alhambra, It was trés charmant. Did you ever see her Mademoiselle?
I was employed by her once, and she is not charmant Monsieur Poirot, believe me. She's poisonously rotten through and through.
Is it possible, Mademoiselle?

Yes. I was her secretary for over five years. I tell you she can be a remorseless fiend. She wants every- thing for herself. She'll give nothing to anybody else ~- no references, no help. And she'll-.use any device to prevent you telling the truth about her.
ARLENA MARSHALL has reached the beach, and stands irresol looking about her. PATRICK REDFERN swims back to the beac with powerful, flamboyant strokes, as if drawn towards he by a magnet.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE TERRACE ABOVE THE BATHING BEACH MORNING

text: The group of POIROT, MISS BREWSTER and CHRISTINE REDFERN is as it was before in Scene 22.

What you say is truly shocking Mademoiselle. Don't you think so Madame Redfern? CHRISTINE REDFERN gets to her feet and waves to her husba In the distance we see him pause, then ignore the wave, a deliberately walk off with ARLENA MARSHALL down the beach Abruptly. CHRISTINE REDFERN turns and leaves the terrace, heading back towards the hotel.  24 25 19 Continued
I think I shall go for my row now. MISS BREWSTER rises and walks off the terrace in the dire of the small harbour. Slowly POIROT shakes his head.
Mais oui. Undoubtedly there is the smell of evil here. POIROT struggles out of the deck chair and strolls down t steps towards the beach.

DAPHNE CASTLE comes out of the sea. Her bathing suit is outstandingly chic. Her gaze is alternating between KENNETH MARSHALL who is lying next to his daughter on the sand taking the sun, and ARLENA MARSHALL and PATRICK REDF who are sitting and talking further down the beach, as POIROT strolls up to her.
Good morning Mademoiselle. What a charming costume.
Why thank you Monsieur Poirot.
The bathing costume can be so un- flattering n'est ce pas?
(looking at Arlena) It is my opinion that ninety eight percent of all the people in this world should never put one on.
Mrs Marshall of course being one of the remaining two percent.
Obviously. It's one of a couple of activities she does to perfection.
The other being?
Adultery.  20 25 Continued
So you think your old friend of seventeen years ago has made the mistake in marrying her eh? She shoots him a shrewd look.
A mistake? It's a silver plated, copper bottomed, gilt-edged, disaster. Still it probably suits him. He always was a collector of lame ducks.
She doesn't look much like le canard poiteux, to me.

Ob you don't understand. He married his first wife simply because no one elise would have her, and when she died he upped and married that shop- worn piece of fluff when she was jilted by Lord Coddington after being cited in his divorce.
Well perhaps Mademoiselle, she makes him the good wife.

Good wives, as they say in Italy, do not grow horns on their husbands' heads. Why only last year that randy old fool Sir George Barry left her every penny of his money, - about one hundred thousand pounds by all account - enough to keep her in single chins for life and I tell you, she didn't get that for her racing tips. Now it looks as if she's got her claws into Patrick Redfern, and that poor wife of his hasn't the faintest idea of how to remove them. It's a pity really, but in the end I suppose all ladies have to learn to defend what they want. Don't you agree Monsieur Poirot. She smiles at POIROT mischievously and walks off along th beach to join KENNETH MARSHALL, POIROT looks after her thoughtfully. He sees LINDA MARSHALL get up and run down the beach towards where PATRICK REDFERN and ARLENA MARSHA  25 21 Continued are talking. Slowly he walks in the same direction. MR BLATT comes splashing up from the sea, in a loud striped bathing suit which makes him look like a corpulent wasp, and intercepts POIROT.
He roars
Good morning Monsieur P. I see they won't get you in the briny in a hurry.
Non. I have never cared for la mer.
Well I suppose you can't teach an old frog new tricks eh? laughs uproariously. HERCULE POIROT is scandalized.
An old frog? ... What can this mean?
Frog ... Froggie ... You know - Frenchman.
(coldly) I am not old, and I am not a Frenchman.
Eh?
Monsieur, I am a Belgian.
I beg pardon. I thought they were all the same, vieux haricot.
Pardon?
Vieux haricot - Old Bean - get it? with laughter again, towelling himself vigorously as he does so. POIROT nods in mystification.
Care to join me for a pre-lunch livener?  25 22 Continued POIROT still looks bemused, so MR BLATT mimes the action drinking.

Ah l'aperitif. Une bonne idee, Before turning back towards the hotel, POIROT looks down beach to where LINDA has joined her step-mother and PATRI REDFERN about thirty yards away. The CAMERA ZOOMS in to j them.
{to Linda) What the hell are you doing here Linda? Did your father send you to play goose- berry, chaperon, or spy?
(panting) I thought I'd just come for a chat Arlena. I don't seem to be having any fun.

Well why don't you go back to the hotel, dahling, and write out five hundred times, I must try not to look so abysmally dowdy, and if you take your own advice you may just get to have some. LINDA flees awkwardly away down the beach towards where POIROT and MR BLATT are starting their walk towards the swimming pool bar. She is sobbing and cursing under her breath.
(to Patrick Redfern) Really, that girl runs like a diseased dromedary. The CAMERA ZOOMS BACK to its previous position. As she passes POIROT and MR BLATT we hear distinctly what she is saying.

The bitch! ... I could kill her! ... I could kill her! POIROT shakes his head at MR BLATT who looks away in embarrassment. They continue their walk towards the bar as the CAMERA PANS off them to where DAPHNE CASTLE is sitting on the beach talking to KENNETH MARSHALL.  23 25 Continued
I know it's none of my business, but if I may presume on an old friendship, I'd like to ask you why you put up with her?
Who?
Arlena of course, She does make you look a bit cheapyboos.
I suppose she does. Still I can cope with it.
Do you think Linda can?
What do you mean?
Well, she's always on at the child, bitching the hell out of her.
Yes. It's a pity about that. Linda's like her mother. She takes things hard.
Then why not do something about it?
Like what for instance?
Like fixing up a divorce for instance. People do it all the time you know - with most of my friends it's almost a full time occupation.
Not with me. A deal's a deal. I don't approve of quick marriage and easy divorce. Arlena is my wife, and that's all there is to it.
Till death do you part?  25 26 27 24 Continued
Exactly.
(thoughtfully) I see.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE SEA NEAR THE BEACH MORNING

text: MR and MRS GARDENER are on a pedal float. MRS GARDENER does the talking while MR GARDENER does the pedalling. Th pass the spot on the beach where ARLENA MARSHALL is talki to PATRICK REDFERN. As they go by, ARLENA takes PATRICK's arm and walks him down the beach, carefully keeping the hand which tickles his neck, screened from her husband.
Look at that. Still up to her old tricks. She hasn't changed a bit. She's man mad ... How much was it she cost us?
Fifty thousand dollars.
And the lawyers' fees. Don't forget the lawyers' fees. How much did you pay Kleinfeld Klauswitz and Stummerhofen? -
Another ten, I guess.
Exactly. Making sixty in all, I could wring her neck. She spits violently into the water.

PATRICK REDFERN and ARLENA MARSHALL walk up to where KENNETH MARSHALL and DAPHNE CASTLE sit together on the beach.  27 25 Continued PATRICK REDFERN waves his hand awkwardly and continues wa on towards the hotel. KENNETH MARSHALL rises and draws AR a@ little apart from DAPHNE CASTLE.
You were very keen that we came here, Now I know why,
Oh really?
Yes. You knew that Redfern fellow was coming here, didn't you? All that baloney when we arrived, about coincidence .,.
Dahling, I swear to you it was the greatest possible surprise. You could have knocked me down with an orchid,
I might just knock him down, and it won't be with anything frail or fancy either.
Dahling, you're so impetuous You know I don't care for anyone but you, She kisses him lightly. He stares blankly pack at her.
You know I often think Arlena that other people are right, and that I'd be much better off without you.
My dahling what are you saying?
I'm saying that you behave unkindly towards my daughter, and that you do me no credit whatsoever, She tosses her head and turns away from him to busy herse with the application of sun tan lotion.

POIROT and MR BLATT are in the swimming pool bar which is run by CHARLIE. MR BLATT drinks a pint of beer.  26 28 Continued POIROT holds a tiny, green, sticky aperitif. In the back- ground PATRICK REDFERN passes by and goes into the hotel.
Tell me straight, Monsieur. What's a famous sleuth like you doing in a place like this?
Simply, I repose myself. I take les vacances.
I suppose it was a stupid question really. You wouldn't tell me even if you were down 'ere on a job, would you now?
Possibly not, but I assure you it is not the case. And as for you, I could ask you the same question. I wouldn't have thought these people here were your tasse de the.

You're right there. Bloody stand- offish the lot of them. No, frankly I came here because it sounded romantic, and well a bit daft - the Jolly Roger Hotel Smugglers' Island set in the Med! I've always had a bit of a thing about Pirates, ever since I was a boy sailing off the Cornish Coast. As a matter of fact I've hired a little yawl to do a spot of it 'ere. Perhaps you'd care to come for a spin this afternoon?
Thank you, but no. I prefer the terra ferma. I wish I could oblige but there it is.

Talking of wishing, I'11 tell you the one about the bloke at the Wishing Well in Ireland. He's a bit upset you see, because sitting next to him is a titchy little piano player, about a foot high, piaying the old joanna for all its worth. And he's saying "No dammit, I did not wish for a twelve inch pianist."  28 29 30 27 Continued MR BLATT goes into gales of laughter. POIROT Sighs.
Well I wish I understood the English idiom better,
Another snort? :
Non merci. I shall put myself in order for lunch. POIROT gives MR BLATT a small bow and walks off towards t hotel.. WE TRACK INTO A CLOSE UP of MR BLATT'’s florid fa as his eyes narrow speculatively.

location: PATH AT THE SIDE OF THE HOTEL MIDDAY

text: POIROT is walking along a path by the side of the hotel. stops to listen as raised voices float out from a first f bedroom window.
And I tell you you're infatuated with her Pat. That's why you insisted on coming to this place - because you knew she'd be here.
What absolute rot! I hadn't the faintest idea.
Don't lie. Whatever you do, don't lie to me.
PATRICK REDFERN is facing his wife CHRISTINE. Both of them are standing near the open window.
Look here Christine, it's not like you to be jealous. Can't I speak to & pretty woman without you being after jumping to the conclusion I'm ... well, having an affair with her?
Well aren't you?  30 31 32 33 28 Continued
Of course not, Arlena and I are just friends that's all.
I don't believe you. Look, she's a bad lot, Pat. She'll do you harm - I know it. Please give it up, and let's go away from here.
No. I absolutely refuse. Here we are, and here we stay. If you don't like it, you can ...
Yes?
Nothing. Just stop being so bloody jealous. He stamps out of the room, banging the door, behind him.
That damned bitch ... I could murder her!

location: PATH AT THE SIDE OF THE HOTEL MIDDAY

text: POIROT, realising that the conversation has terminated continues on his way, sadly shaking his head.

A MONTAGE of evening activities in the lounge. LINDA MARSHALL reads a book. The GARDENERS, DAPHNE CASTLE and MISS BREWSTER play Mah Jong. : Next we glimpse MR BLATT and KENNETH MARSHALL playing billiards. POIROT watches these activites and then makes his way out of the hotel into the night.

location: A CLIFF PATH WHICH LEADS TO AN ARBOUR ABOVE BIBLE

text: POIROT makes his way along a moonlit path which leads to Arbour situated above Bible Bay. There are marvellous  33 34 29 Continued views of the quiet silvered sea lapping an old stone Fisherman's Chapel. The bell on the top of it strikes eleven.
(to himself) The gentle moon, the lesser light. The Lover's Lamp, the Swain's delight, A ruined world, a globe burnt out, A corpse upon the road of night.
(calling) Is anyone there? POIROT makes his way over to the Arbour which is construc of flowered trellis.
CHRISTINE REDFERN sits on a stone bench gazing out over the sea. POIROT enters.
Forgive me if I startled you Madame. I was talking to the moon.
Oh the moon. I suppose everyone does that.
Everyone is a moon, Madame, and has a dark side which is never shown to anybody.
Everyone except me, I think. I wish I could be so secretive and not show what I feel.
Sometimes for ladies that is difficult.
Do you know what I'm most sick of in this place? :
What Madame?  30 34 Continued

Pity. I can't bear to be pitied. Everyone around here is so sorry for me. I can tell by the way they look at me. Poor little thing, they're saying. What she has to put up with from that fool of a husband of hers.
Will you allow me to tell you something, Madame? The Arlena Stuarts of this world do not count. Their domination is of the moment. Really to count, & woman must have either goodness or brains,
You can't actually believe that men care for either of those things can you?
Yes I do. She laughs bitterly. Your husband loves you, Madame. I know it.
You can't know it. .
But I do. I've seen him looking at you. For Hercule Poirot, such an oeillade is enough. CHRISTINE REDFERN. breaks down and weeps on POIROT's shou After a while the weeping subsides.
It's alright. I'm better now, Please leave me. I'd rather be alone. POIROT rises from the seat he has taken during her breakd offers her his bandana which she gratefully accepts, bows and retires.

head_text.subj: EXT. PATH LEADING FROM BIBLE BAY TO THE HOTEL NIGHT

text: POIROT walks thoughtfully along the path which leads from Bible Bay to the hotel. Suddenly he hears the sound of voices coming from behind some bushes, Cautiously he step aside to peer through.  36 37 38 31

head_text.subj: EXT. A TREE SCREENED CLEARING NIGHT

text: In a little clearing screened from the Path by trees ARLE MARSHALL and PATRICK REDFERN stand close together. The latter's voice is loud and clear.
Arlena darling, you know I'm mad for you don't you ... I've quite looped the loop,
Of course you are dahling. And I adore you too, my mad Irish, . She holds out her arms to him and they come together, embracing passionately.

head_text.subj: EXT. PATH LEADING FROM BIBLE BAY TO THE HOTEL NIGHT

text: POIROT, grimacing with embarrassment, hurries away toward the hotel.
Quelle vache de luxe! The elongated shadows of the entwined lovers writhe on th moonlit grass. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
As POIROT nears the hotel he sees KENNETH MARSHALL standi outside it staring fixedly up at the sky.
Good evening Monsieur Poirot, What a lovely night. Not a breath of wind anywhere,

The calm before the storm perhaps, Bon nuit. He enters the hotel, and closes the door behind him. We m into a CLOSE UP of KENNETH MARSHALL's face to see it is suffused with bitterness and rage. He drives his balled fist into the palm of the other hand, making a sharp viol sound in the still night, SLOW MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  39 40 Al 42 32

MR BLATT, whistling a cheerful hornpipe is making ready t cast himself off in a small yawl. He does so, raises the sails and moves out of the harbour, in a South Westerly direction. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT. OUTSIDE STAIRCASE THE HOTEL MORNING

text: LINDA MARSHALL climbs the outside staircase. She wears a bathing costume.
LINDA MARSHALL steps into the corridor, and runs down it. She opens her bedroom door.
LINDA comes into her bedroom. Inside CHRISTINE REDFERN stands awkwardly. LINDA MARSHALL is startled.
Oh there you are!
Yes ... Er, I thought I'd have an early dip.
Good idea. In fact I came in to ask you whether you'd like to come with me to Cutlass Cove this morning.
Yes. I'd love to.
Good, I'm playing tennis at twelve fifteen, so we'd better start fairly early. Half past ten suit you?
I'll be ready. Meet you in the hall, after breakfast. The door closes behind CHRISTINE REDFERN. LINDA MARSHALL looks after her puzzled.  43 33

The CAMERA PANS lovingly over a large selection of silver chafing dishes kept warm on a series of hot plates on the sideboard. We then CUT away to see DAPHNE CASTLE looking disapprovingly at LINDA MARSHALL who is listlessl finishing her meagre breakfast of coffee and toast.
You know you really are naughty Linda. Andrea goes to all the trouble of preparing decent English breakfasts, instead of those weedy Continental affairs, and all you eat is toast.
I'm sorry. I'm not hungry.
Let me at least tempt you to Oeufs Jolly Roger.
What's that? DAPHNE CASTLE removes the cover from a dish and exhibits it.
It's Andrea's lunatic idea of pirate gastronomy. Plover's eggs served in a sheep's skull with crossed marrow pones. Jolly tasty.
I just couldn't - really. DAPHNE CASTLE puts her arms round LINDA MARSHALL.
What's the matter? Is it Arlena?
(nodding bitterly) She's so beastly ...
You don't want to worry about her. Things have a habit of working out - I promise you.
(fiercely) Yes. If you make them!  45 46 35

head_text.subj: EXT, THE TERRACE OUTSIDE THE HOTEL MORNING

text: HERCULE POIROT sits at a table under a beach umbrella dri a cup of coffee, and eating a croissant loaded with mount quantities of strawberry jam. DAPHNE CASTLE crosses from the hotel and heads off in a Westerly direction towards Lighthouse Ledge. CHRISTINE REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL se off in a North Easterly direction towards Cutlass Cove. After a moment POIROT himself rises and moves off in a South Westerly direction towards Booty Beach.

Booty Beach is empty save for ARLENA MARSHALL who is tryi to launch a float, She is dressed in the same white bathi Suit and green cardboard Chinese hat as the day previousl POIROT appears and stands watching her,
Do you require assistance, Madame? ARLENA MARSHALL gives him one of her seductive looks.

Oh Monsieur Poirot, would you? I'm afraid it's a bit too heavy for me. POIROT walks down to the water's edge, but stops when he realises he is wearing white suede shoes. Gingerly he rem them, and puts them carefully with his socks, several fee beyond the tide mark. He then meticulously rolls up his trousers to the knees and walks into the sea. The float i successfully launched, and ARLENA MARSHALL, holding her paddle, jumps on it.
Thank you so much and Monsieur Poirot, please don't tell anyone where I've gone. Everyone will keep following me about so.
Everyone Madame?
Well perhaps some people more than others, But I just want to be alone. With a bright and confiding smile on her face, ARLENA MARSHALL paddles away to the Northwards.  46 36 Continued

(to himself) Ah, ca jamais! ... That I do not believe. She is not the Mademoiselle Garbo, that one. It is quite clear whom she is going to meet. He turns and retraces his steps towards the beach. His wh suede shoes float out to meet him.

Sacre Bleu! The suede is ruined. POIROT wades ashore mopping unhappily at his shoes. ARLEN MARSHALL's float rounds the point and disappears. A furth surprise greets POIROT as PATRICK REDFERN strolls down fr the direction of the hotel. He gapes first at REDFERN, th at the point which the float has just rounded.
The top of the morning to you. You seem to have given your shoes a bath.
Alas it is so.

You know you want to use a wire brush on those things. Salt water does them no good at all. He laughs delightedly. POIROT scowls.- After a moment or two REDFERN's mood changes, and he starts to look about h very obviously puzzled and impatient. KENNETH MARSHALL now approaches from the direction of the hotel. REDFERN eyes him apprehensively, but MARSHALL more or less ignore
Morning Monsieur Poirot. Seen my wife about?
(innocently) Has Madame then arisen so early?
She's not in her room ... I think I'll take my dip right away. I've got a lot of typing to do this morning. Can't abide it, but it's got to be done.  37 46 Continued
You are perhaps an auteur?
What me? Good gracious no. Perish the thought. No, they're pusiness letters. I sometimes think one would have a better holiday if one took one's secretary with one.
I wouldn't have thought that that was such an original thought, old boy.
. (coldly) No, I daresay you wouldn't. MARSHALL takes off his robe and puts it on the sand, next Poirot's ruined shoes.
Hullo, hullo, hullo. Been taking your shoes for a swim?

(gritting his teeth) An unfortunate wave. KENNETH MARSHALL saunters off down to the sea. Behind the back of the unamused POIROT we see and hear MR and MRS GARDENER walking towards us. PATRICK REDFERN looks up eagerly, but is obviously disappointed.
And where is Madame Redfern this morning?

Who? ... Oh I don't know, I think she's gone off sketching somewhere, MR and MRS GARDENER come up with POIROT and PATRICK REDFE and sit down in beach chairs. MR GARDENER fusses about op beach umbrellas for his wife.
Good morning Mr Redfern. Good morning Monsieur Poirot. PATRICK REDFERN mumbles and POIROT bows. Have you been paddling, and forgotten to take your shoes off?  38 46 Continued
Very drole Madame. He smiles thinly.

A friend of ours did something like that once in Miami. Do you remember Eileen Scholenblautwitz, Odell? Her old man gave her a watch for their wedding anniversary that must have cost a couple of arms and a leg, and she went into the water with it. When she came out she found of course that it wasn't working. Do you remember what she said? "The Godammed thing's stopped at eleven diamonds past three rubies".
I thought it was in the morning dear, and she said "three rubies past eleven diamonds."
(firmly) It was in the afternoon Odell, and she said "eleven diamonds past three rubies",

I'm sure you're right dear. We watch KENNETH MARSHALL swimming. He does it well, disappearing under the surface of the water for longish periods. A BRIEF MIX indicates a small time change. Finally he walks up the beach.
Hi there Captain Marshall! Where's Linda this morning?
Linda? ... I don't know. Mooning about the Island somewhere I expect.

You know that girl looks kinda peaky to me. You ought to give her some of that Virol. They say anaemic girls need it. I*ve seen it on the hoardings. KENNETH MARSHALL finishes drying himself, and puts on his
Linda's alright. Excuse me. I've got some work to do, and it's got a bit late.  39 46 Continued KENNETH MARSHALL walks away up the beach towards the hote

If you want my opinion, it's that step-mother of hers that's doing her no good. We knew an only child once whose father married again, didn't we Odell - remember Gloria Stuhlnichsteiner. She grew hair all over her bosom. We hear the sound of someone approaching, and PATRICK RED looks up hopefully, obviously to see if it is ARLENA MARS and then down again sulkily, as we see it is MISS BREWSTE He rises abruptly and starts to walk up and down the beac
Good morning all.
Hi there!
Good morning.
Bon jour, Madame. MISS BREWSTER notices POIROT's spoiled shoes.
What have you been up to Monsieur Poirot. Been trying to walk on the water?

I leave that performance to our Saviour, Madame. My own miracles, if such they can be described, come more from the exercise of the little grey cells, She laughs. And you Madame, - have you had your swim this morning?
Oh yes I had one about ten o'clock. In fact I was lucky to survive. Somebody chucked a bottle out of one of the hotel windows, and nearly brained me.  40 46 Continued
What a dangerous thing to do. Odell do you remember the Angelsturmer kid who got concussion right there in Mid town Manhattan, from a can of tooth- paste falling on his head?
Are you sure it wasn't toilet cleanser, dear. I had the distinct impression that that little Dutch girl on the can came into it somewhere ...
(firmly) Toothpaste!
Concussion you say, from a tooth- paste tin? That does seem rather difficult to believe.

It fell from a forty fifth floor window! MRS GARDENER chuckles to herself. A silence falls. They a watch PATRICK REDFERN impatiently pacing the beach and tu his head continually towards the direction of the hotel.
Where's Mrs Marshall this morning? POIROT shrugs elaborately.
I haven't seen her, But Mr Redfern sure looks mighty put out.

Yes he does, but it's Captain Marshall I really feel sorry for. He's such & quiet man - always so composed, but I'll bet he's actually seething inside. The CAMERA joins PATRICK REDFERN, now some distance away the group of MR and MRS GARDENER, MISS BREWSTER and HERCU POIROT. He saunters around aiming vicious swipes at limpe and crabs, with a piece of driftwood he has picked up. Occasionally he looks up in the direction of the hotel, t falls again to abusing the marine creatures. Back in the group, Miss Brewster gets to her feet.
Well I'm going for my row.  46 47 41 Continued

As for me I shail return to the hotel to change my shoes. It is not agreeable to be seen in this condition. POIROT bows to the company and trudges away in the direct of the hotel holding his wet shoes delicately in his hand MISS BREWSTER walks along the beach in the direction of t harbour. In doing this she has to pass PATRICK REDFERN.
Are you taking your boat out?
Yes,
Mind if I join you.
Delighted.
Let's row right round the Island.
Have we got the time? She consults her watch. Oh yes. It's not eleven thirty yet. Come on. They walk in the direction of the harbour.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE HARBOUR AND SEA MORNING

text: The boat emerges from the harbour with PATRICK REDFERN ro with strong powerful strokes. MISS BREWSTER in the stern regards him with approval. The boat turns to the North ou of the harbour so that the Island is on its right hand si and the open sea on its left.

Good. Let's see how long you can keep that up for ... She waves to MR and MRS GARDENER as they pass the spot on beach where they are sitting. They wave pack. Then the bo passes round the point and they are lost to sight. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  48 49 42
PATRICK REDFERN rows the boat past Lighthouse Ledge. He scans the shoreline anxiously. The boat's progress slows.
Here come on, buck up! You're slacking! PATRICK REDFERN flashes her a charming smile.
To be sure they'd have had you in charge of the galleys in the old days. He digs the oars in and the boat shoots forward. SLOW MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

The boat rounds the next point, and Blood Bay comes into view. Distinctly we hear a chapel bell ringing twelve o'clock. It is quite a small cove facing North West, and the beach above the water line is shadowed by a huge overhanging cliff. A float is drawn up on the peach. A figure of a woman lies sprawled out on the sand, in the shaded part. WE ZOOM IN TO A CLOSE UP to see that her face is covered by a large screen cardboard Chinese hat f under which a long red curl escapes. Bronzed limbs protru from a white bathing suit.
Hullo. Who's that in Blood Bay?
(sourly) Lucretia Borgia.
Who?
You know it's Arlena Marshall as well as I do. You've been looking for her all morning.  49 50 43 Continued He grins sheepishly and alters course inshore.
What are you doing? We don't want to land here.
Oh be a sport. It'll only be for a minute. PATRICK REDFERN jumps out and runs up the beach, waving a shouting. +
Arlena! ... Arlena ... Hi there!
A HIGH ANGLED SHOT of Blood Bay as PATRICK REDFERN runs u the beach waving.

Hi there Arlena ... He reaches the figure and kneels down beside it. Hey, wake up! WE CUT INTO A CLOSE UP to see the bronzed limbs, the whit bathing suit, the red hair curling out from under the bri of the green Chinese hat. In the background we see MISS BREWSTER still in the boat. PATRICK REDFERN touches one o the bronzed arms then pulls his hand away as if stung. Fr MISS BREWSTER's point of view we see him lift the hat off face.
(shouting) My God!
What's the matter?
She's dead .., She's been murdered ... strangled. He drops the hat back to cover the face and runs back dow the beach to MISS BREWSTER, still sitting in the boat.
Are you sure?  44 50 Continued PATRICK REDFERN nods his head dumbly.
How horrible!
Who could have done this to Arlena? ... It's just not possible. My God, if I get my hands on the fiend who did this... MISS BREWSTER looks uneasily around her.
You don't suppose he's still hanging about do you?
(grimly) I hope so...
We must get the Police ... Perhaps one of us ought to stay with the body.
Don't worry. I'11 stay. MISS BREWSTER sighs with relief.

Ob thank you. I'll be as quick as I can. I'll go in the boat ... Can't face that ladder. She points to an iron ladder which is clamped to the clif side, and which leads to the top. CUT BACK TO A HIGH ANGLED SHOT to see MISS BREWSTER row o round the point. 51 INT. DAPHNE‘CASTLE'S OFFICE IN THE HOTEL DAY In her chaotic office in the hotel DAPHNE CASTLE is phoni the mainland, In the doorway hover POIROT and MISS BREWST DAPHNE (on phone) Listen Zoggy, sorry to use the private number - I know Queenie is a jealous cat and makes life hell for you - but we've had a murder ... yes a murder!  52 53 54 55 45

head_text.subj: INT. PRIVATE SITTING ROOM ROYAL PALACE TIRANE DAY

text: KING ZOG flamboyantly dressed in crested smoking jacket paces his private sitting room as he holds the telephone.
My dear Daphne, I simply can't believe it.

head_text.subj: INT. DAPHNE CASTLE'S OFFICE IN THE HOTEL DAY

text: DAPHNE CASTLE on the phone.

Why not for heaven's sake? You have one every ten minutes in Tirane. It's Arlena Stuart - you know - the musical comedy star, Didn't you ever see Sunshine Strippers? She was quite appalling, but the music was jolly. (sings) Sunshine Strippers soaking up the sun. Sunshine Strippers having lots of fun ...
Please Daphne will you concentrate on the murder!
Sorry. Well she's been strangled. Apparently they just found her on the beach wearing a hideous green hat.

head_text.subj: INT. PRIVATE SITTING ROOM ROYAL PALACE TIRANE DAY

text: KING ZOG on the phone,
Never mind the hat. Who killed her?
I don't know. Does it matter - everyone loathed her.
Of course it matters. I'11 send an Inspector of Police.

head_text.subj: INT. DAPHNE CASTLE'S OFFICE IN THE HOTEL DAY

text: DAPHNE CASTLE on the phone.  46 55 Continued

No, don't do that. I've got the best detective in the world here already - Hercule Poirot. Even you must have heard of him. She flashes a smile at POIROT, who preens himself, before turning back to the phone and lowering her voice.
(sotto voce) He's a finnicky little bugger, but a simply colossal brain. (normal voice) He says he must have a doctor to establish time of death and all that. Have you got one you can spare?
Yes. I'll send one, and a policeman. This must be official.
Please Zoggy, can't you keep it quiet? You know how peculiar people are about a spot of murder. The scandal will zap my hotel, and I'm sure Monsieur Poirot will solve it in a jiffy.

head_text.subj: INT. PRIVATE SITTING ROOM KING ZOG'S PALACE TIRANE DAY

text: KING ZOG on the phone.
Alright Daphne, for old time's sake, and against my better judgement, I'll give you forty eight hours. After that it must be official.
You are a darling.

Another thing - I've got a Colonel Race visiting me here. I understand he's an old friend of Poirot's - they worked together recently in Egypt when that American chewing gum heiress was murdered on the Nile. I'll send him too, with anoff the record police sergeant, who speaks a bit of English.  57 58 47

head_text.subj: INT. DAPHNE CASTLE'S OFFICE IN THE HOTEL DAY

text: DAPHNE CASTLE on the phone.
Your Majesty, you are without doubt the spiffiest chum any gal could have. ‘Bye. She hangs up and turns to face POIROT and MISS BREWSTER, winking and making a conspiratorial gesture.
It's all fixed!

A CLOSE UP as the green Chinese hat is removed. ARLENA MARSHALL's distorted, dead face, stares up at us in brigh sunlight. The tongue protrudes and the eyes bulge. We PULL BACK to see the middle-aged, wiry, Albanian Police Surgeon DR MUSA, kneeling down examining her. COLONEL RAC Stands nearby, with an overweight Albanian Sergeant of Police in a scruffy uniform. Also present are PATRICK REDFERN and MISS BREWSTER.
(impatiently) Well doctor what do you make of it?
She was ... He demonstrates strangulation by putting his own hands round his throat, putting his tongue out, and making a hideous choking noise.
Strangled?
Yes strangled - by big, big hands. He flexes his hands dramatically,
What about the time of death?
Three four hours dead, no more.
(to Sergeant) What time is it now?  48 58 Continued
Time to. eat.
The hour. Not the state of your stomach, The SERGEANT holds up three fingers.
Three o'clock.
{to Redfern) When did you find her?
About noon.
It was precisely twelve o'clock when we came in here. I heard the bell on the Fishermen's chapel round the corner in Bible Bay, strike the hour.
Good. Strangled between 11 and 12.
‘ He acts it out as before.
Most helpful. We'll send the body over to the mainland for the post mortem.
Yes. Yes. Chop her up later. Goodbye. DR MUSA packs up his bag and with a formal bow, trudges o the sand towards the ladder and starts to climb up it.
(to himself) Competent enough I daresay, but needs to brush up his bedside manner. (to Sergeant) Outline the position.of the body will you before it is removed.
Outline? RACE demonstrates with a stick.  58 59 49 Continued
Like this.
He starts work to outline the corpse as the CAMERA MOVES to an EXTREME CLOSE UP of its distorted features.

head_text.subj: INT. THE RESIDENTS' LOUNGE HOTEL AFTERNOON

text: RACE and POIROT are alone in the lounge.
It is absolutely extraordinary finding you here Poirot. Wherever there's a juicy murder you seem to pop up like a jack rabbit.
I could say the same thing about you cher Colonel. If it is not too indiscreet of me may I enquire what you were doing visiting le roi Zog?

Dope running if you must know. There's a@ chap I've been after for years - uses a dozen aliases. He's moving the stuff up now from Turkey through the Balkans, and I've had a strong tip off he's round here at the moment. Still we'd better get on with this lot. It looks a very tricky business.

It is true that most people here would have murdered Madame Marshall avec grande plaisir but do not worry mon vieux. .The order and method of Hercule Poirot will triumph in the end. Now I suppose you will want to start by finding out who was the last person to see Madame Marshall alive?
Yes. I have always found they are the most suspicious.
Parbleu! In this case I think you will find that that person was me.  50 59 Continued
What !!
Mais oui. Apart of course from the murderer. I helped her push her float out from Booty Beach at about ten forty this morning. She asked me not to tell anyone where she was going.
Why?
She said she wanted to be alone.
From what I hear, that was not a desire she expressed too frequently.
My own opinion exactly. But who then, did she go to meet? RACE shrugs.
At any event she would have arrived there shortly after eleven o'clock - the earliest time Dr Musa gave for her death,
Exactement. .

So we can assume that she was murdered there, and not transported there after she was killed - which I suppose limits our suspects to those people on the Island, since anyone coming over from the mainland would have been seen.
And no one was?
Not so far as we have been able to find out.
Then let us begin with the husband, if for no other reason than that matrimonial causes provide the motive for the majority of female murders.  60 51

Present in Kenneth Marshall's room are the CAPTAIN himsel POIROT and RACE. He sits in an armchair facing RACE, whil POIROT wanders round the room. picking up and putting dow objects. Standing against one of the walls is a desk with papers and a typewriter on it.

So that is why we thought we would start our enquiries with you, Capitaine Marshall. A callous reason, but sensible, I'm sure you'll agree. After all, you have a very good, very old fashioned motive - jealously.
You think that,
Come, sir. It is a matter of common knowledge here that your wife and Mr Redfern were on terms of the greatest intimacy.
I do not listen to tittle tattle, Inspector. My wife is dead and cannot defend herself.
I'm not asking her to defend herself. If I'm asking anybody, I'm asking you. Were you jealous of her?
Many men have admired my wife Colonel. If I was the type of man who would kill for jealously, I would have killed her years ago.

It has been my experience that all men are the type of men who would kill for jealousy. You, Monsieur must be tout a fait exceptionnel. Mes felicitations. KENNETH MARSHALL shrugs with irritation and turns away fr POIROT.
(to Race) Have you any questions to ask me?  52 60 Continued He rises letters. He hands his pipe.
I would like an account of your move-- ments this morning, please, between eleven and twelve o'clock.
It's quite simple. I was in here typing until I changed to play tennis a few minutes after twelve o'clock. and crosses to the desk, from which he picks up three

Here they are, If you put one of your men to type them, you will find he won't be able to do them in much under an hour ... (to himself) Where is that damned pipe? the letters to RACE, and then pats his pockets for Finding them empty he goes to search for it is a random manner amongst his tobacco pouch, matches and clea on the desk. He fails to find it, and gives up.
What is there to show that they could not have been typed at some other time - say last night for example?

Today is the twenty-fifth. As you will see, these letters are postdated in answer to this one from my stockbroker, posted in London, the twenty-third, and arriving here on this morning's post at about ten thirty. As I was down on Booty Beach with you Monsieur Poirot at a little after ten forty five, you will see clearly that I must have typed them when I said I did.
It would appear so.
Well, if you're still not satisfied, why not ask the chambermaid if she heard the machine going. She was moving about the corridor some of the time, doing out other rooms.
Thank you Captain Marshall. We'll do that. Now can you tell us what you did after you'd finished typing?  60 61 Continued
As I eaid I went to play tennis. The date was for twelve fifteen.
Whom did you play with?
Mrs Castle, Mr Gardener, and Mrs Redfern.
And was everyone there on time?
No. I was the first to arrive. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
53 KENNETH MARSHALL is taking the tennis balls out of their and knocking them over the net. DAPHNE CASTLE arrives.
Hullo ... jolly good to see you.
Hullo Ken. She takes off her sweater.
-,... I think I was there dead on time. Then Mrs Castle joined me.
Did she seem quite normal?
I don't suppose you've seen anything of Arlena this morning have you? I haven't seen her since breakfast.
Quite normal? What do you mean?
I saw her on a float earlier this morning. I think she's up the North end of the Island somewhere.
Was she with anyone?  61 54 Continued
No. She was alone. Though she was probably heading for some sleazy rendezvous with her leprechaun lover? Oh Ken, it's not right for you to let her torture you this way.
I mean did she look agitated, or flushed, or excited in any way?
Don't be silly Daphne. You do exagger- ate everything so. Arlena may be a bit of a flirt but she knows where to draw the line.
No, I don't think so. She looked her usual soigne self.
The only line Arlena's drawn is under a column of figures.
Drop it will you ... Here's Gardener. MR GARDENER arrives and DAPHNE CASTLE and KENNETH MARSHAL move to take up position on one side of the net.
Hi there!
Hullo. Had a good morning?
Sure. Great.
And who was the next to arrive?
Mr Gardener. He must have been about five or six minutes late.
How about a knock up?
(mock scandalized) A knock up!  61 62 55 Continued
Yes. You know ~ a spot of practice till Mrs Redfern comes.
Oh. You should know that in my country, a knock up means something totally different.
Oh really? Surely you can't mean jolly rogering. They laugh and start to play.
And how did Mr Gardener look?
As he always does - like a sober, up- right, henpecked New York attorney.
_I see. Tell me, how much later was it before Mrs Redfern arrived? A QUICK MIX to indicate the passing of time. CHRISTINE RE hurries onto the court.
Sorry I'm late ... I was sketching over at Cutlass Cove and I lost track of the time.
Don't worry about it. Come and play with me.
I don't know, Seven or eight minutes. She said she'd been over at Cutlass Cove and forgotten the time. CHRISTINE REDFERN walks over to join MR GARDENER. MIX THROUGH to the next scene.
POIROT, RACE and KENNETH MARSHALL are grouped as they wer at the end of Scene 60.  62 Continued 56
And to save you the question, she did not look agitated flushed or excited in any way, though of course she had been hurrying.
Thank you, sir.
Anything else?
Just two things, Monsieur. Firstly, will these letters show your investments to have been profitable?
No. I'm afraid they will reveal I have sustained some substantial losses recently.
Secondly, is it true that your wife had quite a lot of money of her own?
She inherited some money recently - yes.
Did she leave a will?

Yes. Alright, I succeed to her property, but I didn't kill her, if that's what you think. (raised voice) I did not kill her! Understand! The connecting door between his and his daughter's bedroo opens, and LINDA MARSHALL comes rushing in.
Oh daddy, daddy! ... What are they doing to you?
It's alright, my darling. It's just a few questions.
But you didn't kill Arlena. I know you didn't.
Perhaps we should have a little talk, Linda. Is that your room?  62 63 64 57 Continued She nods her head.
Good. Well why don't we go in there, and leave your father to himself for awhile. RACE rises and leads the way next door. POIROT and LINDA MARSHALL follows.
RACE stands up. POIROT sits in a rocking chair. LINDA MAR sits on the end of her bed.

Sorry to have to put you through this, Linda, but we have to find out every- thing that might be useful, and that means talking to everyone - understand? LINDA MARSHALL joins her large, bony hands together, and twists them nervously.
Yes.
Good. Then just tell us what you did this morning, after you got up.
I went for an early bathe before break- fast, then I went to Cutlass Cove with Mrs Redfern.
And what time did you go?
We had a date to meet in the hall at ten thirty. I thought I was going to be late, but it was alright. I asked Daphne to come with us, but she was busy ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

A REVERSE CAMERA ANGLE to scene 45, favouring the three l DAPHNE CASTLE, CHRISTINE REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL. In the background HERCULE POIROT sits at his table on the te  64 65 66 67 58 Continued drinking his coffee. DAPHNE CASTLE parts from the other t to go up the path Westwards towards Lighthouse Ledge. CHR REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL strike out North-Eastwards tow Cutlass Cove. WE CUT TO A HIGH SHOT to see the women diverging, and, mo clearly, the topography of the Island, They wave to each before disappearing out of each other's sight.
And how long did it take you to get there, do you think? MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT. PATH LEADING FROM THE HOTEL TO CUTLASS COVE MORNING

text: LINDA MARSHALL and CHRISTINE REDFERN walk across the Isla towards Cutlass Cove. The angle favours LINDA MARSHALL an her eyeline.
Oh I don't know - ten minutes, a bit more maybe. We weren't in any partic- ular hurry. MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT. TOP OF CUTLASS COVE MORNING

text: CHRISTINE REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL arrive on top of Cut Cove, and start to descend the path to the beach. We see scene from LINDA MARSHALL's angle.
And what did you do when you got there? MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

Again the angle favours LINDA MARSHALL. CHRISTINE REDFERN up her easel in the shade provided by the overhanging cli and starts to sketch the cliffs. She does not remove her pyjamas. LINDA MARSHALL takes off her beach wrap and watc oils herself, and lies down in the sun to sunbathe. The C position is on the sea side, South East of Linda Marshall shooting North West.
I sunbathed and Mrs Redfern, sat in the shade sketching. She doesn't like the sun you know. She gets blisters.  67 68 59 Continued
(sketching) Move over, Augustus John.
Oh isn't he the one who's always driving his wife crazy, by having the most tre- mendous affairs with all his pupils ... Oops, sorry.
It's alright. She smiles bravely.
Then what happened? The CAMERA PANS to a CLOSE UP of the shadow of the cliff the beach. MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

The angle favours LINDA MARSHALL and her eyeline. The sun has moved over to the West, and the shadow stretc deeper away from CHRISTINE REDFERN towards the sea. As th shadow touches her, LINDA MARSHALL rises.
Well nothing much. We jawed away, and the time simply flew by ...
What time is it? LINDA MARSHALL looks at her watch.
Twelve o'clock. CHRISTINE REDFERN gets up and puts away her sketch things quickly.
Lord I must fly. I'm playing tennis at twelve fifteen.
O.K. 1'11 have a swim before I come back. LINDA MARSHALL starts to run down towards the sea.
68 69 60 Continued
Don't forget your bathing cap. LINDA MARSHALL retraces her steps, puts on her bathing ca and runs off down to the sea.
See you later. The CAMERA travels down to the sea with LINDA MARSHALL.

. At any rate Mrs Redfern suddenly asked me the time, and I told her, and she had to rush off back to the hotel to change for tennis, and I went in for a swim. I remember I was half way down the beach when Mrs Red- fern called after me I had forgotten my bathing cap, so I had to come back and put it on. What a bore! From the sea, we look back up the beach to see CHRISTINE REDFERN moving quickly up the path to the cliff top. From top she waves to LINDA MARSHALL, who waves back.
And what time was it when all that happened? MIX THROUGH TO next scene.
RACE, POIROT and LINDA MARSHALL are in the same positions they were before, at the end of Scene 63.

Twelve o'clock. She certainly cut it fine for her tennis date. POIROT moves over to look at her watch. It reads three th He takes out his own half hunter from his waistcoat pocke compares it. It too reads three thirty.
Mademoiselle did you love your step- mother?
My father did, so I tried to for his sake.
But it was not easy, was it?
69 Continued 61
She was not my mother.
And she came between your father and yourself?
Yes.
En effet ma petite, you hated her - that's the truth, n'est ce pas? She was always humiliating you in public. You wanted her out of your family. You could cheerfully have wished her dead!
Poirot!

(suddenly hysterical) It's true!...I did... Many many times... Just like I'm sure Mrs Redfern did, be- cause her husband was in love with her ... She was always on at me, taunting me, making me look foolish and childish. She was so cruel ... so cruel ... POIROT stares at her, not moving, giving her time to coll herself. RACE makes to go and comfort her, but POIROT sto
But anyhow wishing someone dead, isn't the same thing as doing it, is it?

Chard) Non, Mademoiselle, it ts not at all the same. One is a pleasurable fantasy - the other takes strength and purpose. It takes the ability to contemplate calmly the bulging eyes, the blackening skin, the last gurgle of exhaled breath. LINDA MARSHALL suddenly gets up, and with a stifled cry r from the room.
Did you have to be so rough on her, Poirot? I mean she's only a kid.

(gently) Mon vieux, I did not suggest anything to her, that she herself has not already  69 70 62 Continued POIROT (Cont) thought of a hundred times and she does have an usually strong pair of hands for a girl of her age.
Alright, I'll accept that. What did you think about her father?
Le bon Capitaine would be more prudent to cultivate an air of | greater tristesse if he does not wish to be suspected of her death.
Perhaps you're right. Well I'li get the sergeant to work on the type- writer alibi - see if he can do them in under an hour - and then we should have a word with Valentino.

in a series of quick cuts we watch PATRICK REDFERN execut ever higher and more elaborate dives into the .swimming p POIROT watches thoughtfully from a concealed place in the arborial surroundings. He is joined by RACE.
Very impressive stuff, eh Monsieur Poirot? He should be in training for the Berlin Olympics.
Mais oui. Those I should like to see. They say there is an American Negro - a man called Jesse Owens - who is absolument formidable!
It's funny but he too doesn't look to me much like a man who has just lost his lady love.
You think he is celebrating? ... C'est possible. PATRICK REDFERN does a final dive, swims to the pool's ed and climbs out. POIROT and RACE move out from their cover to confront him.  63 70 Continued
Good afternoon, Monsieur Redfern. Colonel Race here is of the opinion that vous avez un coeur leger.
And what might that mean?
That you are gay — lighthearted.
Lighthearted! If I didn't do some- thing, I think I'd go off my chump. What's happened is so unbelievable.
Not in my experience, monsieur. I find it quite believable.
(savagely) Obviously you are more accustomed to murder than I am, Monsieur Poirot. You have probably seen quite a few in your time, and have learnt how to behave.

Vraiment and they have also given me many opportunities of observing how suspects behave. And I can assure you that very few of them have been blithe. POIROT and PATRICK REDFERN glare at each other before the latter moves to put on his bathing robe, and sit down at poolside table.
Mr Redfern may I ask how long you had known Mrs Marshall?
About three months. We met at a cocktail party in London.
And had you agreed to meet down here, or was it mere coincidence?  64 70 Continued
No, I must admit it was not coincidence. She asked me to come, and I suppose I couldn't resist. You see I was infatu- ated with her. I'd have done any mortal thing the asked.
You paint a very clear picture of her. She was the eternal Circe, n'est ce pas?
(rueful) She turned men into swine alright! You see deep down I know I love my wife.
Well mon vieux, that does rather establish a motive for the murder n'est ce pas?
A motive - for me? Holy Mother of God why should I have wanted her dead? I was crazy about her.

So you say. But it is possible she had become too importunate, and was making it impossible for you to return to the wife you loved. Many women have been killed in this world, for no other reason than that they became a nuisance.

I assure you it wasn't like that at all. I could have taken off any time I wanted to. Anyway what are you saying? That it was me who killed her? You must know that couldn't possibly be the case. Wasn't I with yourself the whole time tili I went on with Miss Brewster and found her lying dead?
So Monsieur, it is I who am to be your alibi?
Isn't it true? POIROT spreads his hands in a gesture of capitulation.
Helas - oui!  65 70 Continued
Well there you are then.
Eh bien. Whom do you think she had gone to meet at Blood Bay?
I really haven't the faintest idea.
How about your wife? She had a good motive for killing Madame Marshall.
What!!
Absolument. La Jalousie!!

What nonsense. There's no violence in her. Besides how could she have done it? She'd never have been able to climb down that ladder to the beach - she's no head for that sort of thing at all. - And even if she could have, she was no match for Arlena. She'd have been the one to have been murdered. No, if it's jealousy you're after I'd have a go at Ken Marshall. He must be favourite. Now is that all?

For the moment yes. But please hold your- self in readiness to reconstruct for us tomorrow morning your finding of Arlena Marshall's body, with Mademoiselle Brewster. PATRICK REDFERN walks away towards the hotel. Suddenly there is a cracking of twigs in the bushes behin where the two men are sitting. In a flash COLONEL RACE ha risen and parted them to discover DAPHNE CASTLE crouched in a position from where she has been able to overhear ev thing. She rises insouciantly and steps out, favouring bo men with a radiant smile.
You're absolutely on the right track, Monsieur Poirot. Cherchez la temme! She's the one with the best motive. Captain Marshall simply isn't the type.”
So you have been h'eavesdropping, Madame.
Now don't be tiresome Monsieur Poirot. Everyone h'eavesdrops if they've got any sense. As a detective you must do it all the timn  70 7 66 Continued
Madame, I assure you that Hercule Poirot has no need ...

And don't you believe all that guff about Arlena being the stronger..Women fight like tigers when they're losing their husbands - not that I've had too much experience of that sort of thing myself. I mean I tried everything to get rid of Johnnie - strychnine in the spuds ~ bolting to South America, but he clung on like a limpet. If the market crash in '29 hadn't given him a coronary, he'd be here now. Still it showed where his heart was.
Merci, madame. We Will heed your advice.

You do that. She probably battered her with a bit of driftwood or something, and then finished her off with a little pressure on the carot artery, or whatever it's called. Everyone knows about that - all the crime novels are full of it. In fact an eleven year old child did something like that only the other day in Hungary - or was it Crete? ... Anyway I've got to see about dinner. Au revoir. They watch in silence as she walks away towards the hotel
Do you think she was serious about putting strychnine in her husband's food? I mean if she's killed once ...
... She could have killed Madame Marshall? C'est possible. She certainly has the motive.
Really? What might that be?
(thoughtfully) To become herself Madame Marshall. MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

head_text.subj: THE GOLF COURSE THE FAIRWAY OF THE FIRST HOLE AFTERNOON

text: CHRISTINE REDFERN is attempting to play golf. Her appalli lunge at the ball sends it perilously between POIROT and as they come into sight over a rise. They both duck nervo  71 Continued
67 REDFERN comes running across to them.
I'm terribly sorry. You're not hurt are you?
Don't worry. No harm done.
I suppose I should have shouted fore or something, but I forgot. As a matter of fact I'm a complete duffer at this game. I only play to please Patrick.

Do not disturb yourself madame. The re- doubtable Colonel, and needless to say myself, have faced greater dangers in the course of our professional lives. He has learned le sang froid. I have learned the stiff lip. She smiles thinly. They walk
Have you come to interview me?
Just a few questions. But please do not derange your game.
What do you want to know?
Perhaps you could tell us something about how you spent this morning? towards where the golf ball lies in deep rough.
Well first thing this morning at about eight-thirty I went into Linda Marshall's room to fix up with her to go to Cutiass Cove. You see I wanted to do some sketching.
And she was up at that hour?
Oh yes. As a matter of fact she wasn't actually in her room, when I arrived. She came in a few minutes later. She'd been for a dip.  71 72 73 74 68 Continued
What time did you and Linda Marshall leave the hotel?
About ten thirty.
And how long did it take you to walk to this cove?
I don't know. Between ten minutes and B quarter of an hour. : MIX THROUGH TO next scene as CHRISTINE REDFERN takes a wi swing at the ball, missing it completely.

head_text.subj: EXT, THE PATH LEADING TO CUTLASS COVE MORNING

text: The angle favours CHRISTINE REDFERN and her eyeline, CHRISTINE REDFERN is in front of LINDA MARSHALL by a coup of feet.
It was an absolutely spiffing morning, so we just ambled along, chattering away like a couple of magpies. MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT. TOP OF CUTLASS COVE MORNING

text: CHRISTINE REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL arrive on top of Cut Cove and start to depcend the path to the beach. As indic we see the scene froth CHRISTINE REDFERN's angle.
How did you spend your time at the Cove? MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

Again the scene is observed from CHRISTINE REDFERN’s angl She sets up her easel in the shade provided by the overha eliff, and starts to sketch the cliffs. LINDA MARSHALL ta off her beach wrap and watch, oils herself, and lies down sunbathe. The CAMERA position is on the cliff side, North West of CHRISTINE REDFERN shooting South East towards the The dialogue is as in scene 67.  74 75 69 Continued
I set up my easel in the shade and sketched some cliffs. Linda sunbathed.
And the two of you stayed like that? Neither of you moved?
That's right. It was just so peaceful there.
And what time did you leave? The CAMERA PANS to a CLOSE UP of the shadow of the cliff beach. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

The sun has moved over to the West, and the shadow stretc deeper away from CHRISTINE REDFERN towards the sea. This, is seen from CHRISTINE REDFERN's angle. As the shadow tou her, LINDA MARSHALL rises and looks at her watch. CHRISTI REDFERN geis “pand puts away her sketch things quickly, a LINDA MARSHALL starts to run towards the sea. The dialogu as before.

It was twelve o'clock. It had suddenly got quite late you see, and I had to hurry because I had a date to play tennis at twelve fifteen, and I had to change first. LINDA MARSHALL retraces her steps and puts on her bathing in response to CHRISTINE REDFERN's call.
You had your watch with you?
