No. I asked Linda the time. LINDA MARSHALL runs off down to the sea. The CAMERA does not move, but stays with CHRISTINE REDFER she watches the girl rush into the sea.
Anyway I packed up my sketching things as quickly as I could, and went back to the hotel.  75 76 77 78 70 Continued
And Mademoiselle Linda?
She went into the sea. CHRISTINE REDFERN hurries up the path to the cliff top, t CAMERA going with her, but looking out to sea where LINDA MARSHALL is bathing.
Did she enter the water before you left the Cove?

location: CLIFF TOP ABOVE CUTLASS COVE MIDDAY

text: CHRISTINE REDFERN looks down and waves to LINDA MARSHALL the sea. She waves back.
Oh yes. 1 waved to her from the top of the cliff. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: THE PATH FROM CUTLASS COVE TO THE HOTEL/THE OUTSIDE

text: A montage of running shots ending with CHRISTINE REDFERN entering the hotel.
Then I simply tore back to the hotel as fast as I could ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: MR AND MRS REDFERN'S BEDROOM MIDDAY

text: CHRISTINE REDFERN, now in tennis clothes, is tying up the of her gym shoes. She unfastens her racquet from its pres and dashes out of the room.
. and changed into my tennis things. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  79 80 71
CHRISTINE REDFERN hurries onto the tennis court, where KE MARSHALL and DAPHNE CASTLE are knocking up against MR GARDENER. She joins MR GARDENER. Dialogue as pefore.
I then went to the court where I met the others.
Who were ...?
Captain Marshall, Mrs Castle, and Mr Gardener. I played with Mr Gardener. We had a couple of sets, and then ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
POIROT, RACE and CHRISTINE REDFERN have moved about forty from where they were at the end of scene 71. The golf bal in even thicker rough.
... we heard about Mrs Marshall.
Madame, I must 2sk you, were you very surprised at the manner of Madame Marshall's death?
Well of course to be around when an actual murder is committed is so rare that of course it is surprising - sur- prising and shocking. But I suppose she was the kind of woman ...
To whom such a thing might happen? ... Yes. I find that very significant.
Well I mean to say it's true. After all people like her are always mixed up with everything that's squalid and sordid - blackmail, jealousy, violence - every kind of crude emotion.
Why, Madame, did you mention the word blackmail?  80 Continued 72
Er ... I don't know.
Come, you were quite specific. To your knowledge was Madame Marshall being blackmailed? There is a tiny pause during which CHRISTINE REDFERN come a decision.
Yes, Monsieur Poirot. I'm afraid she was.
What!!

I didn't mean to overhear, but I couldn't help it. It was yesterday afternoon. I was coming back from a walk along Mutiny Mile, and as I passed along the cliff above Blood Bay, I heard voices coming up from the beach. Arlena Marshall was saying "It's no use pressing me. I simply haven't got it to give you any more. As it is, my husband is getting suspicious". And another voice - a man's said "What rubbish. You'll pay up or I'll really make things hot for you".
(sarcastic) You'll pay up, or I'll really make things hot for you?
That's what he said.
Parbleu. He must have been listening to too many blackmailers.
(hotly) I'm sorry you think it's a cliché, Monsieur Poirot, but those were the words used.
Did you recognize his voice?
No. He was keeping it low. But it was gruff and a bit hoarse.  80 81 73 Continued
And that's all you heard?
Yes. I'm afraid I walked on rather quickly. It was a bit embarrassing you see.
Yes. I can quite see that. Thank you Mrs Redfern. We'll follow it up. She smiles weakly at them, and hacks furiously at her bal Turf flies through the air as POIROT and RACE beat a retr
Now we are getting somewhere.
You think so?

Well it does explain Mrs Marshall's seemingly inexplicable behaviour this morning doesn't it? Blood Bay is an ideal spot for a rendezvous with this fellow who's blackmailing her. It's accessible only by water or a ladder steep enough to deter most people and a great part of it is invisible from above.

As you say it is an ideal spot for a rendezvous. But explain this to me, mon cher. Why is it not the pitiless and urgent blackmailer who lies dead, but his victim? Is this not indeed killing l'oie qui depose les oeufs d'ors? RACE regards POIROT with surprise. He is obviously impres by Poirot's point. The CAMERA PULLS UP and away. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT. TERRACE OUTSIDE THE HOTEL AFTERNOON

text: The ALBANIAN SERGEANT sits at a table with a typewriter i front of him. Gamely he bangs away at the keyboard typing Mr Marshall's letters.
82 74 Continued

(reading, laboriously to himself) Current difficulties would be solved by investing in Mr Stavisky's companies. Their high yields make a very attractive proposition ... He sighs elaborately and continues. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
MR and MRS GARDENER are playing croquet. Once again, from concealed position, POIROT and RACE stand watching. MRS GARDENER whacks her husband's ball so that it goes scuddi away into the bushes.

Now, Odell I get another turn for hitting you. She takes another shot and goes through a hoop. And I get another one for going through the hoop. She knocks her ball towards the next hoop. MR GARDENER tr off to retrieve his ball. He plays a good shot which puts back near his wife's ball. She whacks it away in another direction, but by doing so puts her own out of position, through the hoop. As her husband's back is turned while h goes to retrieve his own ball, she quite blatantly cheats moving her ball so that she can easily manoeuvre it throu hoop. She does this then whacks it joyfully up towards th finishing post. MR GARDENER looks on in a defeated way, f the bushes where his ball is.
I thought we agreed one had to go through the hoop at the top again, before finishing dear.

You are quite in error Odell. We agreed no such thing. She hits the finishing post with her ball and wins the ga Come along, I'll give you one more game.  82 75 Continued POIROT and RACE emerge from their place of concealment an approach MRS GARDENER. Her husband has quite a long walk back from the bushes to join them.
Hullo there Monsieur Poirot. How goes the investigation?
It marches Madame. It marches. Let me introduce you to my colleague Colonel Race - Mr and Mrs Gardener. RACE smiles charmingly.
How do you do.

My, you British bobbies are all so charming and sympathetic. I remember I lost a bracelet once at the Savoy - we thought it had been stolen - and a delightful young officer came and found it in a vase of roses where it must have fallen from my wrist when I was arranging them. I thought he'd have been mad as hell wasting his time and all. But not a bit of it.
It wasn't a vase of roses, honey. It was a jardiniere in the fireplace.

It was a vase of roses, Odell. Red, long stemmed roses that Hattie Hymenheimer had sent to us. Surely you remember how she and Betty Bernlumbenwitz had sobbed all the way through Carole Lombard in “Lady By Choice" - Men who loved her grew sadder but wiser.

My recollection is that they brought us Arum Lilies, and that it was Joan Bennett in "While Paris Sleeps", they sobbed through. Don't you remember - While Paris Sleeps, Lovers, Wantons and Wastrels are Awake!
For the last time, Odell, it was a god- damned vase of red roses and...  -~ 82 Continued
Mrs Gardener. I'm sorry to interrupt you, but could you give me your attention please.
What? ... Why yes of course.
Thank you. I would like an account of your movements between eleven and twelve o'clock.
Well now, let me see. Odell and I were on Booty Beach the whole time I guess, weren't we Monsieur Poirot. You remember! You were there.

Alas Madame the statement is not quite true. I took my departure from the beach a little before half past eleven, as did Mademoiselle Brewster and Monsieur Redfern. That left the two of you alone. MRS GARDENER laughs shrilly and exaggeratedly.
Gee, I guess it does. Still, you can't really think that Odell and I had anything to do with the death of that unfortunate woman, Monsieur Poirot, now can you?
We have to investigate everyone here madam, I'm afraid.
But neither Odell nor I would hurt a fly.
We are not talking about les mouches, Madame. Had either of you met Madame Marshall before you came here?
(together) No. Never.
(together) Yes. As a matter of fact we had. MRS GARDENER looks daggers at her husband.  82 Continued 77
There seems to be a slight difference of opinion here.
Well, to tell the truth we invested in a Musical Comedy she did in the States, last year. We met her then.
Was it a successful show?
Hell, no. But it had a kind of appropriate name - Gold Diggers of 1934. You see it could have been successful but she left it after a few weeks to go off with some oleo margarine King, and it folded.
As a result of which you lost your money?
I'll say we did.
May I ask how much money you lost?
Sixty thousand clams. RACE whistles.
And so you bore Madame Marshall a grudge?
Well wouldn't you have? But not enough to bump her off. That's crazy talk.
I hope for your sake it is Madame. For you see you would have had all the time in the world to go to Blood Bay between eleven thirty and twelve o'clock and er ... bump her off. Am I not right?
What utter nonsense. I was with Odell on the beach during that time. Wasn't I? MR GARDENER nods unhappily.  82 83 84 78 Continued
Did you not go to play tennis? Monsieur Marshall and Madame Redfern have said you did.
Er ... well yes, that's right.
What time was that sir?
The date was for twelve fifteen.
But you had to change first, surely?
Er yes, that's true. I guess I left the beach about twenty of ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: THE PATH FROM BOOTY BEACH TO THE HOTEL NEARING NOON

text: On the path between Booty Bay and the Hotel, MR GARDENER examining some bizarre rock formations. He straightens up and walks on towards the hotel.
... There are some curious rock formations on the path back to the hotel which I wanted to examine at leisure.
I think it was a little later than that Odell. About ten minutes later, at least.
No, dear, I don't think so. The time was about twenty of twelve, I'm pretty sure.
Did you see anybody on your way back to the hotel? MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: MR AND MRS GARDENER'S BEDROOM MIDDAY

text: MR GARDENER is changing for tennis. His clothes are old- fashioned even for the period, and his racquet is ancient  84 85 86 87 79 Continued
No sir. I saw no one either on the path or in the hotel. I went straight to my room and changed. MR GARDENER looks out of the window.
We see the exterior of the hotel from MR GARDENER's point view in his first floor bedroom. We see CHRISTINE REDFERN hurrying off the path which leads to Cutlass Cove, and in the hotel.
However while I was changing, I did see from my window Mrs Redfern hurry into the hotel from the direction of Cutlass Cove.
What sort of time would that have been? MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: MR AND MRS GARDENER'S BEDROOM MIDDAY

text: MR GARDENER moves away from the window, consults his watc picks up his racquet which he removes from its press.
1 reckon about ten after twelve, or a little later. He leaves the room. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
MR GARDENER arrives at the tennis court, and DAPHNE CASTL and KENNETH MARSHALL who are already there, move to take position on one side of the net.
Who was there when you arrived?
Captain Marshall and Mrs Castle.
Did you notice anything out of place about either of them?  87 88 80 Continued
Out of place?
How shall I put it - a tautness of manner, an unnatural excitement.
Both of them were animated. But I wouldn't Say unnaturally so.
Could you tell me how much later than you was Mrs Redfern in arriving at the court. A QUICK MIX to indicate the passage of time. CHRISTINE RE hurries onto the court, and joins MR GARDENER.
Well now let me see. I was about five minutes late, and she was approximately ten minutes or so after me. I'd say it was around twelve thirty when she got there. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
POIROT, RACE and MR and MRS GARDENER stand on the croquet as they were at the end of scene 82.
And that's all you can tell us?
I'm afraid so. It wasn't till after the game that we heard of the tragedy.
I see.
Au revoir then, Madame, Monsieur. Enjoy passing through the little hoops. He gives them a little bow, and he and RACE walk off in t direction of the harbour, leaving the GARDENERS alone.
(furious) So you had to tell them about all that money we lost. eh? That wasn't very smart of you, Odell. Not very smart at all.
88 89 90 81 Continued
I'm sorry, dear. It just sort of slipped out.
Slipped out? ... It sort of gushed out, like Goddamned Niagara Falls. And why did you have to go and tell them you left the beach at twenty of twelve?
Well I didn't want to lie now honey did I? They always find these things out you know, .

Baloney! Don't you realise that neither of us has got an alibi now? You are a bloody tool, Odell. Sometimes you make me so mad I could ... Oh hell! She strikes off her croquet ball for a new game. The CAME TRACKS into a CLOSE UP of her large hands gripping the to the mallet as if strangling it. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

MISS BREWSTER's large hands grasp the oars of a row boat. PULL BACK to see her taking them out of their rowlocks, p them inboard, and leaping out of the boat onto the harbou where she makes it fast to a bollard. Sitting on two othe bollards are POIROT and RACE. As MISS BREWSTER gets back boat to tidy it and bale out surplus water they rise and over to her.
Mademoiselle ,I would like to hear some more about the incident of the bottle which nearly hit you this morning.
Oh that! Well, it must have been about 10.15 and I was taking a dip on the hotel beach ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: THE SEA ON THE SOUTH EASTERN SIDE OF THE HOTEL MORNI

text: MISS BREWSTER, attired in an antediluvian bathing costume swimming energetically. Suddenly a glass bottle comes hur  90 91 82 Continued down out of the sky, and lands with a great splash right to her. It filis with water and sinks. MISS BREWSTER look up angrily at the hotel windows but is unable to discover which one it has been thrown, because the sun is in her e
... when suddenly this bottle came whizzing out of the blue and smacked down in the water next to me.
(to herself, sotto voce) Bloody maniac!
Did you happen to notice what kind of a bottle it was, or from what window it was thrown?

I'm afraid not. It sank too quickly for that, and when I looked up at the hotel, I couldn't see much because the sun was in my eyes. MISS BREWSTER swims ashore and starts to pick her way ove rocks towards the hotel's outside staircase.
Tres curieux. And now, madame, I should like to know what you did between finish- ing your bathe and coming down to the beach.
Oh I don't know ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
MISS BREWSTER is doing some physical jerks in her room - breathing, knee bends, sit ups etc.
1 changed out of my wet costume, did a few physical jerks, read the newspaper. Why? Is it important?

Parbleu. It is of the very greatest importance! You must see that during this time it would have been quite possible for you to have gone. over to  91 92 83 Continued POIROT (Cont V.0.) Blood Bay, waited for Madame Marshall to arrive there shortly after eleven o'clock, killed her, and then to have returned in time to join us at about eleven twenty on Booty Beach. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
MISS BREWSTER, POIROT and RACE are as they were at the en scene 89. .
D'ye mean climb up and down that cliff ladder? You must be loopy if you think I could do that, with my head for heights.
I'm afraid we have only your word for that unfortunate malady, Mademoiselle.
Well, why should I want to? Just answer me that,
Non. You answer me that s'il vous plait.
I had no reason. -

But that is not.the complete truth. You have already told me that you were em- ployed as Arlena Marshall's secretary for over five years, and that she gave you nothing ~- no references, no help. In fact she used every device in her power to prevent you telling the truth about her. What I wonder could you have meant by that? _ MISS BREWSTER climbs out of the boat onto the jetty to co POIROT.

Monsieur Poirot, I have my skills as a secretary, but as you may have noticed, I am not a pretty girl from Pitman's College who finds it easy to get a job anywhere at three or four pounds the week. So after I was dismissed I wrote an account of my life with Mrs Marshall,  92 Continued 84 MISS BREWSTER (Cont) hoping to serialise it in the tabloid press. I called it The Secret Life of Arlena Stuart - by her Personal Secretary, with the subtitle The Actress Who Lived Up To The Reputation She Couldn't Live Down! Believe it or not, I got immediate and generous offers to publish, both here and in America, but she stopped me.
How Mademoiselle?
Well you see, without realising it I had signed a contract of employment, one clause of which prevented me from publishing any- thing about my former employer whilst ... (she pauses)
Whilst ...?
(reluctantly ) Whilst she was alive.
And now that she is dead, Mademoiselle, you can go ahead - n'est ce pas? She shoots him a terrified glance.
Well I suppose put like that, yes ... but [ assure you I don't know anything about her death. Nothing at all. You must believe that Monsieur Poirot ... you must!

Calm yourself, mademoiselle. You are not the only person here with a motive for choking Madame Marshall to death. Good afternoon. He gives her his little bow. She gives him another scared and then blunders away up the jetty.
Did you see her hands Poirot? They were absolutely enormous.  92 93 85 Continued
Vraiment cher Colonel. Never have I seen so many women in one place with hands that Jim Braddock himself would like to own, It is most strange.

A large pair of hands pound a typewriter. We PULL BACK to see the ALBANIAN SERGEANT still hard at work on Kenneth Marshall's letters. DAPHNE CASTLE stands looking over his shoulder reading what he has typed. POIROT and RACE appear and walk across the terrace toward them.
Well how's it going Sergeant?
Is taking a long time - much more than one hour to do this.
Hullo, What's the poor man trying to do - preak the Albanian speed typing record? She picks up a couple of letters at random and starts to read them. We notice that her hands also are large.
He is trying to prove an alibi, madame.
Whose? Kenneth Marshalls? If his wife was wealthy he certainly needs one. poor love. Was she wealthy by the way?
It appears so, but why do you ask that?
Well look at these letters. Spondulix wise he appears to be up shit creek with- out a paddle.
Pardon? Qu est ce que c'est cette Sheet Creek?
I think Mrs Castle means to imply that Captain Marshall-is in financial difficulties.  86 93 Continued
Mais oui. That he has already told us.
Still Ken never cared about money. I only hope you're satisfied with his alibi.
Certainment we know these letters had.to have been typed between eleven and twelve o'clock this morning - the time of the murder.
He also claims one of the maids who was cleaning the rooms must have heard the sound of the typewriter.

Well, there it is. Ken certainly isn't clever enough to use the old gramophone record trick - you know the one where the murderer records the sound of a type- writer, puts it on the gramophone, and nips out and bops his wife while everyone thinks he's still in his room. POIROT and RACE give her the kind of looks they would bes on a mentally deficient child.
And of course a gramophone does not actually type letters, madame.
No more it does. Silly me. RACE sighs and gives his attention to the SERGEANT.
Well, you can pack it in now. The point's proved. Instead I think you should take a little exercise.
(suspicious) Exercise?

I would like you to time how long it takes to get from the spot at Blood Bay where the body was found, from various points on the island, running both ways.  “on 93 o 94 on 87 Continued The SERGEANT's worst fears have been realised.
Running sir?
Oui. Like the miraculous Jesse Owens.
I don't think that's at all a good idea. In this heat, you'll give the Poor man a heart attack, and we'll have two corpses on our hands. Besides I have all the timings you want.
You have all the timings!
Come I'11 show you. She leads them into the hotel, as the SERGEANT makes a pr ful gesture that she has what they want.

Watched by RACE and POIROT, DAPHNE CASTLE lifts the tarpa off a bulky object standing in the centre of the conserva to reveal a scale model of the island, beautifully worked coloured plaster. It shows the bays, paths, harbour, ligh house, chapel and hotel, all named, with little flags sho the times to various places, sticking up all over it.

There you are. An old chum of mine did it a couple of years ago, when he had a little trouble paying his bill. Be careful of it ~ it's worth its weight in caviar. We move into an ECU of the model as the two men bend to e it. RACE points to the flags.
And these times are walking times?
Slouching times, I'd have said. (pointing) I mean fifty minutes from the hotel to the point of the island! If you jogged all the way, you could do it in half the time.  88 94 Continued

(tracing with his finger from marker to marker) Then let us do that. Half of fifty is twenty-five - so that's twenty-five minutes from the Hotel to the Point. Seven minutes to Cutlass Cove. Eight minutes to Bounty Beach. Ten minutes to Blood Bay. Seven minutes to Lighthouse Ledge. From the Ledge to the Bay five minutes. From the Beach to the Bay twelve minutes, and from the Bay to Cutlass Cove four minutes.

Astounding mental arithmetic cher Colonel! I stand amazed. Eh maintenant, I would like your Sergeant to prepare more little flags for us with the names of the hotel guests on them, to use with this superb model. It will greatly facilitate our enquiry.
I'11 get him on to it.

Monsieur Poirot, I don't wish to be seeming to teach my grandmother to suck eggs or anything but I've changed my mind about the murderer. You see I was reading a magazine story about a woman in Malaya who was drowned by a huge Moray Eel which darted out of a hole and dragged her to the ocean floor, its teeth buried in her throat. and that gave me a new theory - about the Brewster woman, - Did you know by the way she was Arlena's secretary for years and was fired? Well anyway she could have been lurking in the water off Blood Bay when she appeared on that float thing and could have leapt up and pulled her off it ...
Helas Madame Marshall was not drowned, madame. Still less was she gnawed to death.
Well I'1l tell you what. She could have ...
Mrs Castle, forgive me, but as a matter of routine I should like to know where you were yourself between eleven o'clock and twelve noon.  94 95 96 89 Continued
Me? But surely you can't think...
Please Mrs Castle, we have to check everyone.
Well, about ten thirty I went for a walk over to Lighthouse Ledge, and I sat down there to make some notes for my staff meeting at eleven thirty. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
DAPHNE CASTLE is sitting on a bench under the lighthouse, making notes. In the sea below ARLENA MARSHALL paddles by her float in a Northerly direction.
Did you see anybody?
As a matter of fact I saw Arlena Marshall. She paddled by on a float.
Moving towards Blood Bay?
Yes. *
Towards her death?
I suppose so, It had nothing to do with me. About half an hour later I returned to the hotel for my meeting. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
POIROT, RACE and DAPHNE CASTLE are as they were in scene
Can anyone vouch for you?

Of course - practically the whole staff can, from after eleven thirty that is. You see once a week it is my custom to  90 96 Continued DAPHNE CASTLE (Cont) collect them all together to give them a kind of collective boot up the bum. It does them no end of good - particularly the Eyeties - keeps them up to snuff as my old papa used to say. POIROT traces her proposed journey on the model.

But you could have followed Madame Marshall along the cliff top and have been waiting in Blood Bay to strangle her when she arrived just after 11 o'clock. You would have had plenty of time to have returned here for the meeting at eleven thirty n'est ce pas?
What a simply spifflicatingly absurd thing to say Monsieur Poirot.
Is it? I have seen the way you look at Captaine Marshall, Madame, and it seems to me that both you and he share the same motive.
I'm afraid I don't follow your drift at all.
Vraiment? With Arlena out of the way you two would be free to marry.

Me kill for love? I must say it's very flattering of you to suggest it, but I'm afraid I'm far too much of a hardened old trollop for that; and as for Kenneth, he'd never do it in a million years. Why he wouldn't even contemplate divorce when he must have known about every second man she met was throwing a leg over her.

Ah, but even the protector of lame ducks may change when he meets his childhood sweetheart again after seventeen years, and realises he is still in love with her. She looks very embarrassed.  96 97 91 Continued
Monsieur Poirot you have the Frenchman's obsession with the crime passionel.
That is not so madame, but if I had it, it would be a Belgian obsession.
For my part, Mrs Castle, I should like to know what you did after the staff meeting was over.
I had a date to play tennis at twelve fifteen, so I got changed and breezed off to the court. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
ROSAMUND DARNLEY comes into the tennis court. KENNETH MARSHALL is knocking the last of the tennis balls he has taken from their box, over the net. The dialogue is as be
When I got there Kenneth Marshall had arrived but the others hadn't.
The others?
Mr Gardener and Mrs Redfern.
How did Captain Marshall's manner strike you?
E'm not sure I understand the question?
I want to know whether he was quite normal in his behaviour that's all. You know - fully composed?

I've never known Ken Marshall when he's not been as fully composed as a Beethoven Symphony. MR GARDENER arrives and DAPHNE CASTLE and KENNETH MARSHAL move to take up position on one side of the net.  97 98 92 Continued

Your answer is very amusing Madame, put this is a serious matter, and it is very important to us to know your impressions of the people you were playing tennis with. In other words do you consider that any of them could have committed murder in the previous hour?
I'm sorry if I was flippant. In answer to your question everybody appeared to me to be perfectly normal. I don't believe any one of them could have just strangled somebody.
Thank you, Madame.
I believe Mr Gardener was the next to arrive. How much behind you was he?
I'm not sure. Not long. Maybe three or four minutes. A QUICK MIX to indicate the passing of time. CHRISTINE RE hurries onto the court and walks over to join MR GARDENER
Mrs Redfern was quite a bit later. She couldn't have been on court much before half past twelve ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
RACE, POIROT and DAPHNE CASTLE are positioned as they wer at the end of scene 96.
Who won the tennis by the way? DAPHNE CASTLE is as surprised by the question as RACE,
What? Oh they did. Mrs R can sure hit "the jolly old pill" as if she hated it. If you ask me those milk white arms could mince the triceps of a six hundred pound Sumo wrestler.
i
102 93 Continued POIROT has walked round to peer down a telescope mounted on a tripod which is pointing out towards the harbour.
Ah a sail!
We see through the telescope MR BLATT's sailing boat head towards the island.
I think it might be our gallant mariner Monsieur Blatt.
POIROT steps away from the telescope and turns to RACE.
I've been wondering where he's been all day. Let us go down and pipe him ashore. Au revoir Madame, POIROT and RACE head towards the foyer of the hotel.

Of course I'd forgotten Mr Blatt. He's obviously playing a double role, with all those terrible jokes and everything. I wouldn't mind betting he's an old flame Arlene picked up years ago when she was playing Blackpool or Skegness or some other frightful sea side resort, and got her hooks into and reduced to penury. He meets her here by chance and vows vengeance ...
POIROT and RACE keep going determinedly across the foyer and out of the hotel pursued by DAPHNE CASTLE's wild surm
+.» He would find it quite easy to sail round the island and strangle her with one of those clever nautical knots ...
DAPHNE CASTLE watches POIROT and RACE go, her mouth dropp in astonishment at their failure to listen further to her theorising.  102 103 94 Continued
+s. &@ bowline, or a sheepshank, or whatever they're called ... Her voice trails off disconsolately.
The time is now seven o'clock, BILL THE BOATMAN is making Mr Blatt's yawl for him. As POIROT and RACE approach the men it becomes clear that he is telling a dirty story,

You see this old feller, all bent over goes into an Ice Cream Parlour and says to the soda jerk "Ice Cream Sundae please". He replies "Crushed nuts Grandad?", and the old bloke says "No lad. It's rheumatism", MR BLATT laughs loudly and walks up the jetty towards POI and RACE. Behind them BILL shakes his head in baffled incomprehension,
Hullo Monsewer. Old Bill just told me about the murder. I would have to be out on my boat for the day, and miss all the fun, wouldn't I? What a swiz!
This is Colonel Race. Monsieur Blatt. I don't think you will discover that he finds it quite as hilarious as you do.
Well I didn't mean ...
You say you went out sailing this morning? At what time may 1 ask?
Oh, early. About ten o'clock.
Was anyone with you?
Not a soul. I was all on my little owneo.
And where did you go?
South West. The wind was right behind me.
You didn't happen to approach Blood Bay at any time during the morning, did you?
Is that where the dark deed was done? No. I didn't go within miles of the Place. As a matter of fact I haven't seen anyone all day.  103 Continued 95
And that's all you can tell us?
'Fraid so. Not much use I suppose.
Have you any ideas who could have done it?
Well it's obvious, isn't it? Cherchez le hubby.
It may be so, yes. All we know for certain is that Madame Marshall had a secret rendez- vous with someone at Blood Bay this morning.

Well, that had to be Redfern. Though why pick a draughty cove for a bit of nooky beats me. Reminds me of the old one about the wife watching her old man coming out of the sea, and saying to her friend, "Fred goes all blue and stiff when he's been in the water - not that I worry about the colour." Once again MR BLATT cracks up laughing. POIROT regards hi quizzically; RACE coldly.
It wasn't Mr Redfern. We know that for a fact. It was somebody else - a blackmailer for example. °
(blustering) A blackmailer ... Wotcher mean?
(heavily) We believe she was being blackmailed - by a man.
Well don't look at me. That's not my handwriting.
How do you make your money Monsieur Blatt?
It's all perfectly legit. I'm in what you might call Seaside Novelties - you know, tricks, puzzles, saucy hats and picture post cards.  103 104 96 Continued
(murmuring) Quelle surprise!

Listen, if it wasn't Redfern and it wasn't Marshall, I'll bet I know who it was. Has to be. She said she was going to do it. Don't you remember, you were with me on the beach, yesterday morning, when she ran past?
You mean Mademoiselle Linda? Vraiment. She did certainly threaten to kill her step- mother, But she's so young.
There's no such thing, these days. You mark my words. She's the one. He taps the side of his nose with a vast confidential for finger. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
A CLOSE UP of a pile of frilly underwear. We PULL BACL to the maid GLADYS NORRACOTT sorting them out, and tidying t away. POIROT and RACE appear in the doorway.
Excuse me. GLADYS NORRACOTT jumps.
Oooooh. Lord, you startied me.
Sorry. Is your name Gladys Norracott?
Yes that’s me. I were just putting away Some of Mrs Marshall's things. I must say her smalls weren't ‘arf frilly. POIROT's eyes gleam as he fingers the pile.

Ah yes, the foamy cami-knickers, swirling, half seen beneath the dramatically severe lines of the day suits. Extraordinaire!  104 97 Continued GLADYS NORRACOTT gives POIROT a sharp, suspicious look, a snatching the lingerie away from him starts to pack it in the wardrobe.
(sharply) Was there something, sir?
I understand that you were on duty on this floor between eleven and twelve o'clock this morning.
Not after eleven thirty I wasn't. I had to go to a staff meeting didn't I?
Well, before you left for your meeting did you hear the sound of a typewriter coming from Captain Marshall's bedroom?

Yes. I heard him typing away quite steady. POIROT's gaze travels to a huge array of cosmetic bottles up on the dressing table. Identifiable but not over promi is a bottle of perfume labelled Souffle De Mer.
Now I want you to take a look at these botties. Can you tell me if any are missing? She stares helplessly at them.
Lord sir, you'd have to have the memory of an h'elephant to be able to tell that.
What about the other rooms, where I pre- sume there are somewhat fewer bottles?
I can't say I noticed nothing. What kind of a bottle might it be?

Alas that I cannot tell you. Eh maintenant, one last thing I want you to cast about in your mind to see if there is anything odd that you can remember as having happened  104 Continued She looks 98 POIROT (Cont) this morning which you might have noticed, and have forgotten to tell us.
Odd sir?
Yes, Gladys. Odd. Unusual. Out of place. Different to the normal run of things. at him with a doltish expression on her face. POIROT waits patiently. She looks

Well there was one thing, though it was nothing really. Just someone having a bath a bit after twelve o'clock. I mean that's odd or unusual isn't it? Most people have baths in the early morning or in the evening, but not in the middle of the day.
Who had this bath?
I reelly couldn't say. I just heard it going down the waste that's all.
You're sure it was a bath - not one of the hand basins?
Quite sure. I mean you can't mistake bath water running away, now can you? It makes a kind of gurgling sound.
Like someone choking?
Sort of, yes.
Or being strangled? at bim wide-eyed, her hand flying to her mouth. DAPHNE CASTLE appears in the doorway, and sees only GLADY
Do get on with your work Gladys. You're not paid to gawp.  99 104 Continued GLADYS NORRACOTT hurries out. DAPHNE CASTLE now sees POIR
Oh it's you Monsieur Poirot.
A votre service, Madame.
I'm afraid it's no use questioning Gladys about anything. She's as dense as dough.
I have not found it so, Madame.
Really? Well have you arrested anyone yet? I told you who it was.
Your choice of murderer has so far been somewhat extensive.

Has it? Well I can’t stop now and sort it out for you. I've simply got to keep an eye on Andrea. He's making a curry de Poulet Vindaloos for dinner, and the last time he cooked it, it was s0 hot we practically had to call the fire brigade from the mainland. Arriverdutch as they say in Holland.
Au revoir encore Madame. She bustles out. RACE and POIROT follow slowly.
She's quite potty. She’1l be accusing us next.
Do not distress yourself about Madame Castle, mon vieux. Order and method will prevail.
I sincerely hope so, but then why all these irrelevant questions of yours about baths and bottles? They walk through the door.  105 INT. 106 100

head_text.subj: THE MAIN LANDING OF THE HOTEL EVENING

text: POIROT and RACE walk out onto the main -landing.

There is nothing irrelevant about my questions, je vous assure. They are eminently the most logical. If you have an empty bottle on your dressing table, or in your bathroom, what do you do with it? Do you drop it in the waste paper basket, or do you go to the trouble of going out onto your balcony and hurling it into the sea?
H'm, I see what you mean. You would only do that if you didn't want to be connected with it.
Exactement.
And the bath? What is so strange about the bath?

The time - a little after twelve o'clock. Consider which of the guests were in the hotel at that hour. Madame Redfern. Monsieur Gardener. Madame Castle and Capitaine Marshall. They were all about to play tennis - a curious time to choose to take a bath, n'est ce pas? See you at le dejeuner. POIROT heads off to his room to change for dinner leaving RACE to descend the stairs thoughtfully.

head_text.subj: THE DINING ROOM OF THE HOTEL NIGHT

text: All the guests are seated at the table eating the curried BERT and CHARLIE are the waiters in attendance.
By George this is hot ~ but absolutely super!  o~ 106 Continued He laughs. 101
You're right. It's hotter than a night in a Mexican whorehouse. The others ignore him.
I hope you're not going to be ill, Odell, like poor Mrs Auschsteiner- boltz's girl Sadie. Do you remember how she was when she ate the hot chillies in Alberquque?
Dear, I thought it was Gazpachio in Mexico City.
It was hot chillies in Alberquque, and all night long she was up and down to the john, which was about half a mile away.
Are you sure it wasn't an earth closet, Mrs Gardener? She smiles insouciantly at MRS GARDENER who glares back.
(to Bert) Could I please have a glass of iced water,
Good idea. For me too please. About a gallon of it. A chorus of "Me toos". POIROT rises to his feet.

Mesdames, Monsieurs, talking of water, I would like to disturb you all from the excellence of your dinner for a moment, by asking you just one simple question, which may have some bearing on our murder. Did any of you have a bath this morning about midday, or a few minutes later?  106 Continued 102 The CAMERA moves round the circle of faces, They all shak their heads. POIROT turns to RACE.

Voila! Another little mystery to torture the logical mind. A bath poured out, which no one will admit to taking. (to the Company) Please continue to consume the dish of the incomparable Andrea, and leave to my little grey cells the elucidation of the puzzle why cleanliness is not next to truthfulness. He taps his forehead and resume his seat as we FADE TO BL

location: TOP OF CLIFF ABOVE BLOOD BAY/CLIFF LADDER

text: RACE is finishing strapping an apprehensive POIROT into a Bosun's chair on the cliff top. He crosses himself devoutly, as he is swung out over the side of the cliff a lowered by the SERGEANT. RACE himself descends into the b by the iron ladder clamped to the cliff face, enjoying as he does so the grotesque sight of his colleague swinging around in the air above his head like a helpless whale.
Ma foie! Quelle vie de boheme!
(calling) What's that you say?
(testy) I said my liver! What a life of a Bohemian!
(calling) I wouldn't be worrying about Bohemians if I were you, at this moment. I'd just hang on tight. POIROT looks down and nearly faints with terror at the sh drop below his dangling feet.
Quel horreur!
Don't look down.  103 107 Continued RACE climbs smartly down the ladder singing blithely:
(singing) He flies through the air with the greatest of ease That daring vieux Belge on the flying trapeze.
Mais c'est bien impudent tout cela! RACE leaps off the ladder and is in time to catch the wil gyrating POIROT, and release him from his harness.
Well done Poirot. That should have juiced up the little grey cells for you.

They have not been juiced. They have been paralysed. After considerable attention to his toilet POIROT recover himself enough to take an interest in his surroundings. A the sergeant descends the iron ladder, he walks over to t taped outline figure lying above the waterline in the sha of the overhanging cliff. The green Chinese hat lies over spot where the face would be, and the white bathing costu is spread out over the trunk of the body. He studies it intently. Behind him the sergeant picks up a couple of ob ‘from the beach.
I have found these on the sand. He holds out a pair of scissors and a pipe stem. POIROT and RACE study them curiously.
Right. Hang on to them will you. (to Poirot) Do you think they're significant?

Mais oui. As significant as a wristwatch, a bathing cap, a bottle, a bath... The bell on the fishermen's chapel round the corner in Bi Bay. sounds twelve o'clock faintly: --- and the chapel bell. (he looks at his watch) Bon. It is’ precisely the same time as yesterday when the body was discovered.  104 107 Continued PATRICK REDFERN rows the boat with his passenger MISS BRE in the stern, round the point and in towards the shore. PATRICK REDFERN jumps out and runs up the beach.
Well done. You are precisely on time. Now remember you are to do exactly as. you did before.
I shouted to her I think.
Good. Well off you go.

(shouting) Arlena! ... Arlena ... Hi there! PATRICK REDFERN runs on up the beach waving, and shouting Hi there Arlena ... He reaches the figure and kneels down beside it. Hey, wake up! PATRICK REDFERN touches one of the outline limbs and then sharply pulls his hand away as if stung. He lifts the hat the face.
(shouting) My God!
What's the matter?
She's dead ... She's been murdered strangled! He drops the hat back to cover where the face would be an runs down to MISS BREWSTER who is sitting in the boat hol the oars.
Are you sure? PATRICK REDFERN nods his head dumbly. How horrible!
Who could have done this to Arlena? ... It's just not possible.  105 107 Continued 108 PATRICK REDFERN looks at POIROT who has been watching the reconstruction with great attention.

We stayed like this for a minute or so. You see we were shocked. We didn't know what to do. Then in case the murderer was still hanging about, I volunteered to stay with the body while Miss Brewster went to fetch the police. I touched nothing other than to make sure she was dead.
And I rowed away back to the hotel. I couldn't cope with that ladder you see.
I quite sympathise, Mademoiselle. POIROT walks thoughtfully about the cove examining the cl Suddenly he stops and beckons to RACE:
(shouting) Come here Colonel. Look at this. RACE joins POIROT and sees what POIROT has found - a narr gap in the cliff face. They squeeze through it.
POIROT and RACE stand in the cave. It is faintly lit.
H'm. The air's quite fresh. POIROT sniffs delicately.
Indeed. It smells of le Souffle De Mer.
What's that?
The breath of the sea.
H'm. Very poetic. The two men look about them, examining the cave in detail Suddenly, POIROT looks at a shelf high above his head.

One might perhaps see that there is nothing up there.  108 106 Continued RACE stretches up a long arm, but is still too short for effective search by about a foot. Somewhat precariously h manages a toe-hold in the cave wall, and hoisting himself is now able to investigate the shelf properly. Suddenly h whistles and descends abruptly. In his hands is a tin box labelled Sandwiches.
Ah a picnic box.

A curious place to hide the egg and cress sandwiches, would you not say, mon vieux? RACE opens the box. WE TRACK in to a CLOSE UP to see that the various compartments, labelled Salt, Pepper and Musta are all full of what looks like salt. RACE wets a finger and tastes some.
Good God! ... Not egg and cress, Poirot. Heroin! ... So my information was correct ... What a lucky break! The fellow I've been looking for is obviously using this place as a drop or a cache.
What a fortunate find, mon cher. Now all you have to do is have a watch kept and you will soon know who it is

Exactly. It will give that idle Sergeant of mine something to do. RACE puts the sandwich box back where he found it. You know, I've been thinking. It could be that Mrs Marshall was an addict, and came here yesterday morning to meet’ her supplier.

Non. Non. Non. It is not possible. She had steady nerves, and radiant health. But of course there is always the possibility that she discovered this business accidentally and was Silenced. Alons. Let us return to the hotel. POIROT and RACE leave the cove.  107
110 POIROT and RACE emerge from the cave. POIROT looks first the bosun's harness and then at the poat. Each object dra a shudder from him.

Alas, I stand between the Scylla of Vertigo, and the Charybdis of Mal De Mer. (he shrugs massively) It is true one does not die of Mal De Mer, whereas another journey in that infernal machine might well induce une crise des nerfs from which I would never recover. (to Patrick Redfern) Would you permit me, Monsieur, to prevail on Mademoiselle Brewster for your place in her boat.
Please go ahead. I'11 use the ladder.

You are too amiable. PATRICK REDFERN gives POIROT a dazzling smile and walks a across the beach towards the ladder. He is followed by RA POIROT meanwhile walks apprehensively down the beach towa the boat, in the company of Miss Brewster.

All you have to do is to hop in Monsieur Poirot, and leave everything else to me. Gingerly he complies with her suggestion. As soon as he i settled she casts off, and jumps into’ the boat making it lurch sickeningly. As POIROT groans unhappily she bends t the oars. Back on the beach the sergeant conceals himself unhappily behind a rock. The CAMERA TRACKS to ECU outline figure on the sand. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

ECU model replica of Blood Bay. A hand comes into shot an places a marker with Arlena Marshall's name on it, in the middle of it. We PULL BACK to see POIROT leaning over the model. RACE stands watching.

Now from my own unhappy experience I know it takes about twenty five minutes to row from Booty Beach to Blood Bay, so it is clear Madame Marshall arrived there at approximately five minutes past eleven. Between then and twelve o'clock, she was  108 110 Continued POIROT (Cont) murdered. Let us see where everybody claims to have been during those fifty five minutes. As he speaks each suspect's name, he places their marker the appropriate time also written on it, in the relevant place, sometimes using two markers when the person named from one place to another, during the period under review

Capitaine Marshall was in his room typing. Monsieur and Madame Gardener were on Booty Beach until eleven forty when Monsieur Gardener returned to the hotel leaving his wife alone. Monsieur Redfern was on Booty Beach until he left with Mademoiselle Brewster to go for a row a little before eleven thirty. Mademoiselle Brewster herself arrived at Booty Beach about eleven twenty after exercising in her room. Madame Castle was at Lighthouse Ledge until she returned for her staff meeting here at the hotel at eleven thirty. Madame Redfern and Mademoiselle Marshall were here at Cutlass Cove until twelve o'clock, when Madame Redfern left to go back to the hotel, leaving Mademoiselle Linda alone. Finally Monsieur Blatt was out here sailing in a South Westerly direction. Now what does all that tell us? RACE points to the relevant markers.

That the only people with watertight alibis are Captain Marshall with his hour's typing, Mr Redfern who was either in your sight, or Miss Brewster's. and Mrs Redfern and Linda Marshall who vouch for each other,
Exactement, and nearly everybody had a motive for killing her.
The exception being Mr Blatt.
And even he for an innocent man seems to be very nervous,
Poirot I must confess to you that I find this whole case most baffling. Have you any idea who it is?  110 1il 112 109 Continued
I know who it should be. As I told you before, this is a very slick crime. Something tells me it is not a first attempt.
I'm not sure I follow you.
Come let us take the little promenade and I will explain. MIX THROUGH to next scene
POIROT and RACE walk down the promontory to the Fishermen Chapel.

I must tell you, that earlier this year I was retained by the Trojan Insurance Company to investigate a case of strangul- ation which the police were satisfied was the work of a madman or tramp, and not of the obvious suspect - the husband who ben- efited from the Insurance Policy. I read the documents and decided it was useless to investigate, because the husband had an obviously cast iron alibi, being on a train miles away at the time of the murder. Now suddenly I am not so sure, that incredible as it may seem, I Hercule Poirot, did not make the bad mistake. He looks crestfallen.
Come on Poirot. You mustn't reproach yourself. We all make mistakes.
Not me.
Oh really Poirot! Sometimes you are impossible. They enter the Chapel, with RACE laughing and POIROT affr

head_text.subj: INT. THE SEAMEN'S CHAPEL BIBLE BAY DAY

text: The interior of the Chapel is small and ancient, carved o of stone and crossed with rough wooden tiles. A cross POI watched by the still chuckling RACE stops to examine a sc illustrating the parable of the talents made out of shell  110 112 Continued
(frosty) Ah, the Parable of the Talents. I'm sure you have always believed, that unto everyone that hath shall be given, but from him who hath not shall be taken away, haven't you cher Colonel.
Have I Poirot?

Mais Naturellement, Surely you have always known that to he who doesn't enquire, nothing shall be revealed. Par example, you should enquire what the Insurance Company case has to do with this one, instead of laughing like the jack hass.

I'm sorry Poirot. I really am. Perhaps you would be good enough to explain. POIROT is mollified by RACE's apology and he graciously consents to explain while the CAMERA examines carvings of skulls and gargoyles, martyrs and devils in a short bizar montage.

Can't you see they share the same pattern - the cold blooded plotting, the strangulation, the cast iron alibi of the husband. Mon vieux, I want you to do something for me. I want you to get me photographs of all the witnesses in that case - the husband, the hiker who found the body, everybody who was interviewed. The name of the murdered woman was Alice Corrigan. Her husband's name I think was Edward, and the crime took place near Ilkley, Yorkshire.
That shouldn't be too difficult. The Police probably won't have any photo- graphs but the local press would almost certainly have taken some at the Inquest.
Good. I would also like to have a report on the financial affairs of the murdered woman.  111 112 Continued 113 114
I don't think I will be able to get you any of this information before tomorrow evening, I'm afraid.
Do not distress yourself, mon cher. While we wait we will amuse ourselves.
Amuse ourselves?
Absolument. We shall have un grand pique-nique. RACE stares at POIROT in astonishment, as the chapel bell strikes the hour.

DAPHNE CASTLE and POIROT lead the way through open countr They are followed by the two male servants BERT and CHARL in uniform, carrying hampers. Behind them come the guests MR and MRS GARDENER, MISS BREWSTER, MR and MRS REDFERN, KENNETH and LINDA MARSHALL. MR BLATT walks at the rear by himself. The procession moves. into more thickly wooded countryside. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

The procession of guests and servants enter a wooded glad through which runs a stream, and over which is a narrow wooden bridge. POIROT spreads his arms wide, and indicate he is satisfied with the venue.
Voila, mesdames, messieurs. A perfect place for le dejeuner, sur l'herbe.
I suppose Andrea's splendid Goose Pie might as well be ravished by ants here, as elsewhere and me too for that matter!
Do you remember Odell when we were given those Reindeer Marrow Bones at Modesty Tausburphimmel's home in Pittsburgh?  112 114 Continued 115
I thought they were elk bones, dear.
They were Reindeer Bones, and they were charred black. I remember particularly as there wasn't a thing to eat on them. No wonder she keeps her figure.
Well I'n not going to worry about my figure today, Daddy. I'm going to gorge myself silly.

Quite right, darling. I'm sure Daphne would be most offended if you didn't. KENNETH MARSHALL and DAPHNE CASTLE exchange meaningful glances. The guests spread out and the servants BERT and CHARLIE start to unpack the hampers supervised by DAPHNE CASTLE. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT. GLADE WITH STREAM LATE AFTERNOON

text: It 1s a couple of hours later. Many of the company are asleep or resting in their previous groupings. BERT and CHARLIE are packing up the plates and cutlery. POIROT has crossed the river, and is sitting, comfortably replet beneath a tree. He yawns, stretches, and suddenly gets to his feet, as his attention is caught by a large spread of Datura. He next sees CHRISTINE REDFERN walking on the other side of the river and calls to her.

(calling) Ah Madame Redfern, come and look at these flowers. Ils sont tres extraordinaires!  113 ao 115 Continued 116 CHRISTINE REDFERN runs across the narrow wooden bridge. S joins POIROT and PATRICK REDFERN and examines the flowers
They're very pretty.
And pretty deadly, Madame.
Really? ...What are they?
Les Trompettes De La Mort.
The trumpets of death?

Exactement, Monsieur. Datura. A highly toxic solanaceous plant. Paralysis and death occur with quite astounding swiftness. Yes - all in all, a most lethal weapon ... CHRISTINE REDFERN, who has been about to touch the flower draws back her hand sharply.
. and a most successful picnic don't you think?
Oh ves, very, even thougn there's stiti a murderer walking about loose among us.
For not much longer, Mousieur, Croyez-moi. The CAMERA moves to a CLOSE UP of the Datura flowers. We MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
POIROT walks about, deep in thought, amongst the jumble o rocky caverns which form Keelhaul Caves. Suddenly he is hailed by RACE who comes hurrying across the shingle towa
Ah Poirot. I've been looking ail over for you.  114 116 Continued
Sometimes it is necessary to repose the mind in solitude. One must not blame the little grey cells for their moments of misanthropy.
Well, did you have a good picnic?
lt was most illuminating, and in a certain way quite surprising.
Really? In what way may one ask?
Gastronomically. The Goose Pie was merveilleuse. Have you any news?

Yes. Whilst you have been surprising your stomach, I have been finding out about Mrs Marshall's financial affairs. In a nutshell her bank told me that out of the hundred thousand pounds left to her last year, she has drawn out in cash amounts all but eight thousand. To my mind, this certainly confirms the blackmail story.
Ah ca c'est tres interressant!...And the photographs? When may I expect them?
I should have them tomorrow morning. They will be radioed to Tirane and brought here.
Bon. I am convinced they will prove my case.
So now you know who it is?
Yes. I know.
Well?  116 117 118 115 Continued
I do not like to speak until I have the proof.
How about a clue then?

Mais certainement. It is not as you might expect from your study of detective fiction, the least likely person. Au contraire. It is the most likely person. He smiles disarmingly as we MIX THROUGH TO the next scene
A shadowy figure climbs down the cliff ladder at Blood Ba and crosses the stretch of sand to the concealed entrance to the cave. It finds it and slips inside.

In the dim light, the figure crosses to the shelf, and ma use of the toe hole in the cave wall reaches up and searc the shelf. Two powerful police torches suddenly stab out the darkness and light up MR BLATT as he grasps the sandw box.

Bon soir, Monsieur Blatt. Have you come here to tell us one of your so’ amusing stories? MR BLATT spins round and tumbles down from the perch into arms of the SERGEANT. POIROT rises from a shooting stick. He is elaborately muffled against the night's chill.
Christ Almighty!!
What's it to be this time? Something spicy about dope running?
Alright, alright. It's a fair cop. But how you found out, beats me.
If it's any consolation to you, it was a bit of luck really. We do get them every so often you know.  118 119 116 Continued
Moi I am always interested in the activities of lone sailors, particularly ones who are fascinated by pirates and smuggling.
Me and my big mouth! Well, at least you can't hang me for it.
Pour quoi pas? It gives you a good motive for murdering Madame Marshall.
What!!
You ran your stuff in here. She caught you at it, and threatened to blow the gaff and you topped her.
Now look guv'ner, you can't pin murder on me. That's not my game. I swear I never even spoke to the lady, let alone laid a finger on her. You've got to believe me.
Believe the word of a heroin smuggler - why should I? What do you think Poirot?

I think you should hold him here until tomorrow, when all shall be revealed. Meanwhile even a Hercule Poirot becomes fatigued, so perhaps you would be so amiable as to row me back to the hotel - with as much stateliness as you can command. POIROT leaves the cave followed by RACE and the SERGEANT, the latter taking a firm grip on the cowed figure of MR B

location: THE RESIDENTS' LOUNGE OF THE HOTEL MID-MORNING

text: The guests of the Jolly Roger Hotel sit round facing the fireplace in a large semi-circle. MR and MRS GARDENER sit to the right of the fireplace, and next to them in order are KENNETH MARSHALL, LINDA MARSHALL, DAPHNE CASTLE, PATRICK and CHRISTINE REDFERN, MISS BREWSTER, and last of all to the left of the fireplace HORACE BLATT. Behind  119 120 117 Continued MR BLATT stands the SERGEANT. There is a general excited buzz of conversation which is suddenly stilled as HERCULE POIROT enters the room and takes his place in the centre the semi-circle, standing before the model of Smugglers' Island which has been moved from the conservatory into th lounge.

Mesdames, Messieurs, I have asked you all to meet me here this morning, because I have discovered the identity of the murderer of Madame Marshall. There is a further buzz of surprised conversation, and POIROT takes a small bow.

It is at the moment only a theory, - though one which I am quite sure is. the correct one. However, thanks to the good offices of my dear colleague Colonel Race, I am hoping that certain proofs will arrive shortly, which will put the matter beyond doubt. Meanwhile I shall, with your kind permission offer you Hercuie Poirot's solution. Another buzz of affirmation.
Eh bien, let us begin with a reconstruction of the events at Blood Bay at the time of the murder. We MIX THROUGH TO the next scene, as POIROT points with a pencil to Blood Bay on the model.

The scene is a flashback to scene 107. POIROT is examinin the taped figure lying above the waterline in the shade of the overhanging cliff, watched by RACE and the BERGEAN The green Chinese hat lies over the spot where the face w be, and the white bathing costume is spread out over the trunk of the body. PATRICK REDFERN and MISS BREWSTER arri in the rowing boat, and the former runs up the beach and goes through his reconstruction, kneeling by the outline figure, lifting the hat off the face, then replacing it and running down the beach towards MISS BREWSTER in the boat.  118 120 Continued 121

I visited the scene of the crime at twelve noon the following day, that is to say the same time the body was discovered. I was struck at once by one very interesting fact. Madame Marshall had been obviously lying in the shade. And yet as I learned from the reconstruction her face had been covered by her great big green Chinese hat. Why, I asked myself was her face shielded from a non- existent sun? There could only be one answer - the murderer had wanted it concealed. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
The scene is the same as it was at the end of scene 119. RACE enters holding an envelope which he waves affirmativ at POIROT. They nod at each other.
But why mes amis had the murderer wanted it concealed? He looks directly at PATRICK REDFERN who stirs uneasily i chair.
Why?
1 think you know very well why, Monsieur Redfern.
What can you mean?

I mean that everyone here at this hotel had the opportunity to kill Madame Marshall, except for you and Madame Redfern. She hadn't got the opportunity because she was with Mademoiselle Linda in Cutlass Cove. (he points to Cutlass Cove on the model) And you hadn't got the opportunity since, as you correctly informed me,  121 Continued 119 POIROT (Cont) 1 was your alibi during the whole time until you left the harbour with Miss Brewster, to row rouna@ the Island. He points to Booty Beach and the Harbour on the model.
Well there you are then. If we are the least suspicious of all the people here, why should I know why the murderer had wanted to conceal Arlena'’s face with the hat?
Because the singular impossibility of you and your wife having done the crime, convinces me beyond doubt that you actually did do it.
What!! Is it daft you are?

No, I don't think so Monsieur Redfern. ft is my belief that Arlena Marshall went to Blood Bay to meet you, and that she did meet you, and that you killed her there as you planned to do! PATRICK REDFERN bounds to his feet
Jesus. You re talking through your hat- POIROT shakes his head slowly. D‘you mind telling me how J did it then?

Hercule Poirot 1s not to be fooled twice, mon petit assassin. You did it an the same way that you murdered Alice Corrigan at llkley earlier this year,with the able assistance of your wite or partner Christine, who helped you here, in the same way as she helped you then, by pretending to discover the body of Alice Corrigan at least twenty minutes before Alice Corrigan actually died, and while you were still on the train.  120 4121 Continued
(suddenly furious) Lies! .,. All bloody lies!
Calm yourself, Patrick. As he said himself he can't prove anything. It's only a theory.
What about this proof of his that's coming eh? What about that now?
Don't let him fool you. He just said that to get you to talk. Can't you see that?
Quite right girl. Let him blather away. (ironic) Pray continue, Monsieur Poirot.

Merci. Vous est trop gentil ...Let me say at once that the crime depended 6n the character of Madame Marshall. From the start I saw she was the archetypal victim. It wasn't she who fatally attracted men. It was men like you who fatally attracted her - an adventurer, a man of good looks and easy assurance who makes his living out of women, and often ends up killing them. In other words you were the most likely suspect.
(hotly) Now that's enough.
(warningly) Patrick! PATRICK REDFERN relaxes, grinning boyishly.

I have no doubt in my mind, Monsieur Redfern, that you found it quite easy to get Arlena Marshall to hand you large sums of money from time to time, for "investment", That was how she lost her money, wasn't it? There was  121 122 121 Continued POIROT (Cont) no blackmailer, nor never was. She was a pure invention of your wife's to account for her depleted bank account. PATRICK and CHRISTINE REDFERN exchange uneasy glances.
If anything at all of what you're saying were true, d'you mind telling me why on earth I should kill her. Presumably there would have been plenty more where that came from.

Not so, mon ami. There was very little left. And it wasn't going to be very long before her husband was going to start asking awkward questions about who had swindled her. She would have told him, so you had to kill her in order to avoid a long speil in jail. N'est ce pas? PATRICK REDFERN shrugs carelessly.
It's a tale for the little people, Monsieur Poirot. Why don't you show me how I did it, if you're so clever?
As I say, you did it with the aid of this woman here, who may or may not be your wife. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
A flashback to scene 29. PATRICK and CHRISTINE REDFERN stand by an open window, in their bedroom, rowing loudly over his attentions to Arlena Marshall.

From the moment you came here both of you played out a series of care- fully rehearsed scenes in such a manner that all might hear, or see. Together there were scenes of hysterical jealousy, boomed out through open windows ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  123 124 125 126 122

head_text.subj: EXT. THE TERRACE ABOVE THE BATHING BEACH MORNING

text: A flashback to scene 22. POIROT and MISS BREWSTER are talking together and are joined by CHRISTINE REDFERN. The recessed dialogue we hear is from "I suppose it's a bit like heights. Some people can't stand them ..." to "I don go brown, I just become like a cassata - pink skin, white blisters and green in the face".

. Apart, you Madame, took every opportunity to give the impression that you were a physically frail woman who was absolutely terrified of heights, and who had to hide her skin away from the sun, because it blistered and made her look like an Italian ice cream ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: INT. THE ARBOUR OVERLOOKING BIBLE BAY NIGHT

text: A flashback to scene 34. CHRISTINE REDFERN is sitting on stone bench in the Arbour, crying on Poirot's shoulder.
... and who was altogether to be pitied as a poor little, helpless abandoned wife. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: EXT. A TREE SCREENED CLEARING NIGHT

text: A flashback to scene 36 ARLENA MARSHALL and PATRICK REDFERN stand close together in the glade declaring their love for each other, and embracing passionately.

. Whilst you, Monsieur, took elaborately indiscreet pains to advertise your romance, by virtually shouting declarations of love, instead of whispering sweet nothings ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
A flashback to scene 46. PATRICK REDFERN impatiently paces the beach turning his head continually in the direc of the hotel.  126 127 128 123 Continued

.. and pacing moodily about like a sulky love-lorn poet. But as I say I was convinced the pair of you were play acting, and 1 was determined to prove it, by finding you Madame, out in a perfectly obvious lie. To this end I arranged une pique nique ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene

head_text.subj: EXT. GLADE WITH STREAM LATS AFTERNOON

text: A flashback to scene 115 POIROT is examining the Datura flowers. He sees CHRISTINE REDFERN walking on the other side of the river, and calls to her. CHRISTINE REDFERN runs across the narrow wooden bridge. She joins POIROT and examines the flowers.

.. and during the course of it induced you to cross a narrow bridge over running water which I had previously selected. If it were true you had a bad head for heights you would have had a great difficulty crossing that bridge. Madame, I must tell you, I saw no such difficulty. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

head_text.subj: INT, THE RESIDENTS' LOUNGE HOTEL MID-DAY

text: The company are grouped as they were at the end of scene CHRISTINE REDFERN is looking murderously at POIROT.
That means nothing. I was in a hurry, and probably didn't take notice.
lf your affliction had been genuine you could not have helped taking notice. But it was not, and I knew you were lying about it, and I also knew why.
(shouting) Then why for God's sake?  128 129 130 124 Continued

If you only have patience Madame, I will now describe to you what you both did. (to Patrick Redfern) The first move you made was on the beach on the day previous to the murder ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene as he points to the terrace above the hotel beach on the model.

head_text.subj: EXT, THE TERRACE ABOVE THE BATHING BEACH MORNING

text: A flashback to scene 24, We pick up the scene where CHRISTINE REDFERN gets to her feet and waves to her husba in the distance. We see him pause, then ignore the wave, and deliberately walk off with ARLENA MARSHALL down the beach. Abruptly CHRISTINE REDFERN turns and leaves the terrace, heading back towards the hotel.

-.. You arranged a clandestine meeting with Arlena Marshall in Blood Bay, for the following day. She was to go round to the Bay early. Nobody went there in the morning when it was in shade, and you were to join her there as soon as you could slip away undetected. You told her that if, while she was waiting for you, she heard anyone descending the ladder, or a boat came in sight, she was to Slip into the cave ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

location: OUTSIDE STAIRCASE SOUTH EASTERN SIDE OF THE HOTEL

text: PATRICK REDFERN creeps furtively out of the hotel, using the outside staircase. He is wearing a bathing wrap, unde which he is holding something bulky. He runs off in the direction of Blood Bay.

.. You left the hotel early in the morning, and ran over to Blood Bay. Under your bathing wrap you had concealed a green Chinese hat - the duplicate of the one Arlena Marshall was in the habit of wearing ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  131 132 133 134 125
PATRICK REDFERN climbs the ladder into the Cove. He then takes the Chinese hat from under his wrap and conceals it behind a rock, and climbs up the ladder.

.:» You climbed down the ladder and stowed it away in an appropriate place, out of sight, before returning to the hotel. In the meantime you, Madame Christine had gone to Linda Marshall's room ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.
CHRISTINE REDFERN enters LINDA MARSHALL‘'s bedroom and al her wristwatch, putting it fifteen minutes forward - an action we see in CLOSE UP.
, and advanced her wristwatch by fifteen minutes. LINDA MARSHALL enters the room and the rest of the scene flashback to scene 42

. You then arranged the expedition to Cutlass Cove and returned to your own room ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene. INT. PATRICK AND CHRISTINE. REDFERN’S BEDROOM MORNING CHRISTINE REDFERN applies dark sun tan to her legs and ar She then throws the bottle out of the window.
+». where you carefully stained your vaunted white arms and legs with dark sun tan and then threw the incriminating bottle out of the window ...

location: THE SEA ON THE SOUTH EASTERN SIDE OF THE HOTEL MORNI

text: Flashback to scene 90. MISS BREWSTER is swimming. The sun tan bottle comes hurtling out of the sky and lands with a great splash near to her. It fills with water and sinks. MISS BREWSTER looks up angrily at the hotel windows but i  134 135 136 137 126 Continued unable to discover from which window it has been thrown, because the sun is in her eyes.
... where it narrowly escaped hitting Mademoiselle Brewster who was bathing.

head_text.subj: INT. PATRICK AND CHRISTINE REDFERN'S BEDROOM MORNING

text: CHRISTINE REDFERN is putting on a white bathing suit simi to Arlena Marshall's. Over it she puts on a pair of beach pyjamas.

_... You then dressed yourself in a white bathing costume similar to the one worn by Arlena Marshall, and over it a pair of garish beach pyjamas with long floppy sleeves and a high neck, which effectually concealed your newly browned limbs and chest. You then went off to Cutlass Cove with Linda while 1 made my way to Rooty Beach ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene
Flashback to scene *2 from where ARLENA MARSHALL paddles away on her float to where PATRICK REDFERN arrives, and looks about him, puzzled and impatient.

... At about eleven forty Madame Marshall departed for her rendezvous. and a minute or two later you Monsieur Redfern appeared, and after some laboriously comic remarks about my suede shoes, you set about registering baffled impatience. And now, mes amis the scene moves to Cutlass Cove... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

A flashback to an amalgam of scenes 68 and 75, this time shot from a neutral position. The action is from whe LINDA MARSHALL rises and CHRISTINE REDFERN asks the time to where LINDA MARSHALL enters the sea and CHRISTINE REDF leaves the cove - only this time we see in CU CHRISTINE REDFERN picking up LINDA MARSHALL'S watch which she has t  137 138 139 127 Continued ‘ off and left behind her on her first visit to the sea (be being reminded of the bathing cap), and putting the hands back fifteen minutes to 11.45.

. At eleven forty five, and keeping her own watch concealed, Madame Christine asked Linda the time. Naturally she said it was twelve o'clock. She then starts to go down to the sea. While her back is turned, Madame Christine returns the watch to the correct time. Then she calls Linda back telling her she has forgotten her bathing cap. Why should she bother to do that, you may ask? The answer is simple, On top of the Fisherman's Chapel in Bibie Bay, there is a bell. Fifteen minutes later it was due to strike the hour, and if Linda heard it the game would be up. True, as I knew from Mr Blatt's evidence that the wind was South West, and therefore blowing away from her, but Madame Christine could take no - chances of the sound carrying. A girl splashing about in the sea and wearing a bathing cap would hear nothing.

location: CLIFF TOP ABOVE CUTLASS COVE MID-DAY

text: CHRISTINE REDFERN looks down and waves to LINDA MARSHALL in the sea. She waves back. CHRISTINE REDFERN now strikes Westward along the path to Booty Bay, rather than Southwa to the hotel.
Now she hurries from the cove ...

location: . PATH BETWEEN CUTLASS COVE AND BLOOD BAY

text: CHRISTINE REDFERN runs as fast as she can along the path which separates Cutlass Cove from Blood Bay. Over it we see superimposed POIROT's finger tracing the journey on t model.

... and over the path which separates Cutlass Cove from Blood Bay. This takes her about four minutes. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  140 141 128 EXT. TOP OF BLOOD BAY MiD-DAY CHRISTINE REDFERN strips off her beach pyjamas and puts them and her sketching things behind a rock. She then climbs agilely down the ladder.
. She then strips off her beach pyjamas, and hides them and her sketching things behind a big rock which is there, and climbs athletically down the ladder ... ‘
ARLENA MARSHALL is on the beach. She sees CHRISTINE REDFE descending the ladder.
(to herself sotto vote) Christ! She runs into the cave.

Arlena Marshall is on the beach, wondering why you, Monsieur Redfern are taking so long to come. Suddenly to her great chagrin, she sees you, Madame, coming down the ladder. Only her husband could have presented a more inconvenient figure. Of course she is forced to take refuge in the cave ... CHRISTINE REDFERN takes the green Chinese hat from its hi place behind the rock, pulls out a false red curl from in it, and lies down on the beach above the water line. She arranges the hat over face so that it is hidden, and the curl shows to advantage.

.».-Then all you had to do was to take the green Chinese hat, with I suspect a false red curl pinned underneath the brim at the back, from where your > partner had hidden it earlier in the morning, and dispose yourself in a sprawling attitude with the hat and curl shielding your face and neck. All this has taken you at the very most a further five minutes. The timing is perfect. <A few minutes later the church bell strikes twelve o'clock,  141 129 Continued POIROT (V.0. Cont) and the boat containing Mademoiselle Brewster and Monsieur Redfern comes round the point ... From CHRISTINE REDFERN'S P.O.V. we see the row boat conta MISS BREWSTER and PATRICK REDFERN come round the point. He jumps out, runs up the beach waving and shouting, and kneels down beside the body. We see the bronzed limbs, the white bathing suit, the red hair curling out from under the brim of the Green Chinese hat from HIS POINT OF VIEW. He touches one of the bronzed arms, then pulls his hand away as if stung. He then lifts the hat off the face. In EXTREME CLOSE UP we see CHRISTIN REDFERN's face. She winks up at PATRICK. He grins broadly before replacing the hat, and starting his dialogue with BREWSTER.

It is of course Monsieur Redfern who runs up the beach, who bends down to examine the body. It is he who is stunned, shocked, broken by the death of his lover. All Mademoiselle Brewster had seen was a body with sun tanned limbs, wearing a white bathing costume and Arlena's hat. Do you remember what I said the first day we met, Mademoiselle? All bodies lying on the beach are alike. They're not men and women There is nothing personal about them They are like rows of butchers’ meat grilling in the sun, And it’s true. One moderately well made young woman is very like another. Two brown arms; two brown legs; and a little piece of bathing suit in between. MISS BREWSTER starts to run off back to-the hotel.

... No wonder you were fooled into imagining that you had seen the corpse of Madame Marshall, when what you had actually seen was the live body of Madame Christine Redfern. Oui, that was why the murderer had to conceal the face - because it was not the murder victim lying there, but somebody else. And who else would help Monsieur Redfern but his own partner, or wife. Yes, the crime had the same pattern as the  141 142 130 Continued POIROT (V.O. Cont) Corrigan murder, with the victim being killed later than everyone thought possible. And now the performance by the witness is over. She has been chosen well, She has not got a good head for heights, 50 will not attempt to climb up the ladder. She will leave the Bay by boat, taking the long way back for help, and leaving Monsieur Redfern to remain with the body in case "the murderer was still hanging about". And what do you think happened Mademoiselle Brewster, as soon as you disappeared? ... As soon as the boat is out of sight CHRISTINE REDFERN jum up and cuts the hat into pieces with a pair of scissors, which she drops in her haste. She then fills the prassier of her bathing suit with the pieces of cardboard. Quickly she kisses PATRICK, then turns, runs across to the ladder swarms up it, and disappears. PATRICK REDFERN tosses a broken pipe stem down on the beach.

... Madame Christine jumps to her feet, cuts up the green cardboard hat into pieces she can conveniently stuff into her bathing costume, and swarms up the ladder. The only clues they leave for us are the pair of scissors which I'm sure she dropped unintentionally, and the pipe stem of Capitaine Marshall's pipe which they put there in the hope that it would incriminate him...

head_text.subj: EXT, CLIFF TOP ABOVE BLOOD BAY MID-DAY

text: On the cliff top CHRISTINE REDFERN puts on her beach pyja gathers up her sketching materials, waves gaily to PATRIC below, and runs off.
.. On the cliff top she slips back into her beach pyjamas gathers up her sketching things ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  143 144 145 146 147 131
